The S&P BSE SENSEX is a stock market index comprising 30 financially robust companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. One of these companies is Tata Motors, which is traded on multiple exchanges, including the Bombay Stock Exchange, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is a Southeast Asian country located on the Indochina Peninsula. With a population of approximately 92.7 million, it is one of the most populous countries in the world and Asia. Vietnam shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The country has experienced significant economic growth since 2000 and had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among major economies in 2011. Vietnam is one of the few remaining one-party socialist states that adhere to communist principles.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film, marking the directorial debut of John Gatins, who also wrote the screenplay.

Bhagat Singh, a charismatic Indian socialist, gained fame through his revolutionary acts against the British in India. His execution at a young age transformed him into a revered folk hero, inspiring the Indian independence movement.

Aparshakti Khurana debuted in Bollywood with the 2016 Indian biographical sports drama film 'Dangal', starring Aamir Khan. The film, directed by Nitesh Tiwari, revolves around a wrestling competition.

James VI and I, also known as James Stuart, was the monarch of Scotland, England, and Ireland from 1567 to 1625. Despite ruling over two separate kingdoms with distinct political systems, he advocated for a unified parliament, aiming to merge the Scottish and English parliaments. His reign in England was marked by challenges and conflicts with the Parliament.

Danielle Cormack, a New Zealand actress, is renowned for her diverse roles across stage and screen. She began as a core cast member in the soap opera 'Shortland Street', but gained recognition for her parts in 'Xena: Warrior Princess', 'The Cult', and 'Legend of the Seeker'. Cormack's film credits include 'Separation City', and she's appeared in TV series like 'Rake' and 'Underbelly: Razor'. Her most notable recent work was playing Bea Smith in the prison drama 'Wentworth' from 2012 to 2016.
Rob Sheridan, an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, is renowned for his significant contributions to the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor and comedian known for his roles in various comedy films. He starred in "Tommy Boy," "Black Sheep," and the "Joe Dirt" franchise, including the 2015 sequel "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser," which he also co-wrote with Fred Wolf. Spade has been a part of successful comedy ensembles in movies like "Grown Ups" and its sequel.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop, Lady Gaga's album, received mixed critical reviews but achieved commercial success. It debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200, selling 258,000 copies in its first week and becoming her second consecutive US number-one album. The album sold 757,000 copies in the US and was the ninth best-selling album of 2013 globally, with 2.3 million copies sold.
John Frusciante's final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, was released in 2006. It marked the last time Frusciante featured as the band's guitarist before his departure in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, a significant figure in British politics, served as Prime Minister and introduced policies known as Thatcherism. Her legacy is debated, but she is recognised as a powerful and impactful leader.

Michael Andrew McKagan, also known as Duff McKagan, is an American musician, singer, and songwriter who has also gained recognition as a writer. He contributes weekly columns on diverse subjects to various online platforms, including SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor known for his diverse body of work, including acting roles, narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially known as ValÃ¨ncia, is the capital of the autonomous community of the same name in Spain. It is the third-largest city and metropolitan area in the country, with approximately 800,000 residents in the administrative centre and a total population of 1.7 to 2.5 million in the metropolitan region.
Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and Sarah Michelle Gellar in the subsequent television series.
The series 'Make It or Break It' concluded with its third and final season, which aired its finale on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a field that combines linguistics, computer science, and engineering to enable computers to understand and convert spoken language into text. It has various applications, such as voice control, data entry, document preparation, and speech-to-text. The industry has seen significant progress with the adoption of deep learning methods by major companies like Google, Microsoft, and Apple, leading to the development of advanced speech recognition systems.

Richard Alf, an American businessman, was a co-founder of the renowned San Diego Comic-Con International, which began as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970. Alf, along with Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, established the convention, which later became known as the "San Diego Comic Book Convention." Alf served as its chairman from the inception.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 martial arts film Fist of Fury, originally starring Bruce Lee in the lead role.

Rory McIlroy is in contention to win his first title since May after carding a third straight five under-par 67 at the Turkish Open. He is tied with Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat and one shot behind leaders Victor Dubuisson and Jaco Van Zyl. McIlroy, who is targeting a third Race to Dubai title, overcame a slow start to his round and showed resilience after an ankle injury earlier in the year.

Sheikh Ali Salman advocates for a national dialogue in Bahrain, urging the government to propose concrete solutions and engage in meaningful negotiations. He emphasizes the need for a representative of the royal family, preferably the reform-minded Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, to participate in the dialogue. Sheikh Salman highlights a previous agreement with the crown prince for a constitutional monarchy, which was disrupted by the intervention of Gulf troops. He expresses hope for more active US involvement under Secretary of State John Kerry and criticizes the UK's private approach, urging public pressure on the Bahraini government to end violence and human rights abuses. Sheikh Salman also calls for the release of opposition leaders and the continuation of peaceful demonstrations as a means of pressuring the government.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and scholar, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He was a pivotal figure in the early-music movement, founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and leading it for three decades, during which they performed globally and produced over 200 CDs. Hogwood's academic prowess and generosity were widely recognised, and he held esteemed positions at various universities. His contributions to the music world, particularly in historically informed performance, have left a lasting impact, as evidenced by tributes from colleagues and the enduring success of the AAM.

The homicide rate in Scotland has reached a historic low, with 57 victims recorded in the year ending March 2016, a decrease of five from the previous year. This is the lowest annual figure since 1976 and half the number from nine years ago. The report 'Homicide in Scotland' highlights that sharp instruments, particularly knives, remain the primary method of killing. Despite the overall positive trend, concerns were raised about the accuracy of previous statistics and the high rates of sexual and violent crimes in Scotland.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland in the Premier League, despite taking the lead with Dan Gosling's goal. This was Bournemouth's first goal in three games, but they failed to capitalise on their chances, including against 10 men after Steven Pienaar's red card. Sunderland's Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe scored, securing Sunderland's first win of the season. Bournemouth's manager, Howe, expressed disappointment, stating they had enough opportunities to win multiple games.

Summary: The Australian Prime Minister, Mr Abbott, defends his country's controversial immigration policy, which involves detaining migrants and sending them to offshore camps. He argues that stopping boats carrying migrants is necessary to prevent deaths at sea. Mr Abbott's comments, comparing IS to Nazis, sparked criticism from Australian Jewish groups, who deemed the comparison inappropriate. The New York Times editorial criticised Australia's approach as brutal and inhumane, warning against its adoption by Europe.

The US has suspended talks with Russia regarding the Syrian conflict, citing Russia's failure to uphold the ceasefire agreement and its involvement in attacks on civilians and humanitarian aid. Russia denies these accusations and blames the US for the breakdown of negotiations. The situation in Aleppo is dire, with heavy aerial bombardments, civilian casualties, and a lack of access to humanitarian aid. The US and Russia will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations in Syria to prevent further escalation.

A think tank report suggests selling high-value vacant homes to fund social housing construction. This could generate Â£4.5 billion annually, building 80,000-170,000 social homes. The proposal aims to address the housing crisis and reduce the social housing waiting list. However, critics argue it could displace low-income families from desirable areas, creating segregated communities. Labour proposes using a bank bonus tax to fund affordable homes and create jobs in the construction industry. The report's director defends the idea, saying it's about fair allocation of housing, not denying housing rights. The proposal is controversial, with concerns about its impact on social cohesion and the potential creation of ghettos.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, passed away at his home, amidst a measles epidemic in the city. An initial examination couldn't confirm measles as the primary cause of death, and an inquest will be held for further investigation. Mr. Colfer-Williams had a history of asthma and recently sought medical attention for a rash. His family is perplexed as to how he contracted measles, as no close relatives, including his vaccinated daughter, have the disease.

Vincent Hudson, a 54-year-old man from Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16, which allegedly occurred in 2001. He is scheduled to appear at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Neil Aspin's Gateshead and Adam Lockwood's Guiseley played out a 1-1 draw in a closely contested National League match. Guiseley took the lead in the first half through Jake Lawlor, but Gateshead equalised in the second half with a well-taken goal by Wes York. Both teams had chances to win it, but the match ended in a draw, extending both teams' unbeaten runs.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, intends to replace two stands to expand the stadium's capacity. This decision comes as an alternative to the previously proposed new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has faced delays due to a town green application. The club's majority shareholder, Steve Lansdown, announced that the redevelopment will commence in May, provided there are no judicial reviews during the six-week waiting period after signing the Section 106 agreement.

Cuadrilla Resources has halted shale gas drilling, or "fracking", in Lancashire following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The company will review data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding to resume operations. The BGS confirmed the tremors' proximity to the drilling site and noted that water injection during fracking can cause earthquakes. The process is controversial due to environmental concerns, but a UK parliamentary committee advocated for its support with proper regulation. The BGS is monitoring the situation, and Cuadrilla expects the analysis and consultation to take several weeks.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of fraud after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes, despite not collecting funds for the charity. He denied three counts of fraud, with the jury clearing him of two counts. Carpenter claimed he was busking and had permission to use the banner as a tribute, not for fundraising. Sentencing is set for January.

Ipswich Town secured a convincing 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers in a Championship match. Grant Ward and Luke Varney's goals, along with a QPR keeper error, set up the win. Ipswich could have scored more, but QPR's Sandro hit the post late on. The result lifted Ipswich to 14th, above QPR, who struggled in attack and defense. Ipswich's manager praised his team's performance, while QPR's manager acknowledged their weaknesses and called for mental toughness.

Luke Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, excelled in the T20 Blast tournament last season, achieving a notable strike rate of 138.69. He expressed enthusiasm for the club's positive trajectory and praised the coaches for fostering an environment that motivates players to strive for excellence.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a convincing 29-12 win over third-placed Chinnor, thanks to standout performances from Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams. The team's strong defensive effort, particularly from the front row and front five, contributed to their success. With upcoming matches against lower-ranked teams, the Reds have an opportunity to climb the table, but their coach emphasizes the need for continued improvement, building on their recent emotional and determined display.

A 28-year-old man named Nazrul, a suspected Bangladeshi citizen, has been arrested for the rape of a 74-year-old nun in India. This arrest is the sixth in the case, with police identifying eight suspects in total, two of whom remain at large. Nazrul was apprehended at a Kolkata railway station based on a tip-off, after he had fled to Bangladesh. The incident sparked widespread outrage and protests across India. The attack, which occurred in March, involved a gang that stole money and ransacked a convent school before the nun was assaulted.

The passage introduces an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, the founder of a London museum dedicated to brands, packaging, and advertising. The video explores the factors influencing consumer buying habits, such as technological advancements (domestic freezer and washing powder) and global trade (cheaper imports). It also examines the shifting landscape of brand ownership and popularity in the UK, encouraging viewers to engage with interactive elements and additional resources for further exploration.

Two elderly women in different Scottish towns have been targeted by phone scammers claiming to be from BT. The scammers gain remote access to their victims' computers and steal substantial amounts of money. Police are urging people to be cautious when receiving cold calls and to never disclose banking details over the phone, as legitimate organisations would never request such information.

Duffy, a former professional rugby player, has been appointed as the new coach of Featherstone on a one-year contract. He joins from Swinton Lions, where he was the assistant coach, and will lead the team in their upcoming match against Toulouse. The Featherstone chairman praised Duffy's coaching abilities and his achievements at Swinton, despite challenging circumstances. Duffy's appointment marks a new chapter in his coaching career, building upon his 16-year playing experience in the sport.

A woman was rescued from Sker Beach by the RNLI and coastguard after sustaining head injuries from a horse riding accident. She was treated for her injuries and exposure to the cold before being airlifted to hospital.

A global flight tracking system using satellite technology has been approved at a UN conference in Geneva. This decision comes after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in 2014, which exposed weaknesses in the current ground-based radar tracking system. The new system will utilise a dedicated radio frequency to receive transmissions from aircraft, known as ADS-B, allowing real-time tracking worldwide. This move addresses the issue of 70% of the world's airspace currently lacking coverage. The UN's aviation organisation has set a deadline for November 2016 to implement new tracking guidelines, which will require aircraft to send their position at regular intervals.

A boy, Julian Hernandez, who went missing at the age of five, has been found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez has been arrested and charged with tampering with records. The FBI, working with local police and a national centre, confirmed the boy's identity after receiving a tip about his difficulties applying for college. The boy's mother has been informed of his recovery, and his father is being held in jail with a substantial bail amount. Authorities had previously suspected the father's involvement in the boy's disappearance, as he had fled with the child in 2002.

A fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's site in Duncan Street disrupted train services and travel. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste, citing fire safety concerns. The firm was deemed broadly compliant with fire safety laws by the fire service, but the EA revoked their environmental permit due to potential risks to residents, transport, and the environment. The fire service had visited the site multiple times in the past year and raised concerns with the EA in February. The company has until August 7 to appeal the decision, and the cause of the fire is still unknown.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, has proposed two bills in response to the situation in Ukraine's Crimea region, where pro-Russian sentiments are prevalent. The first bill suggests that a referendum or request from a territory's leaders could initiate the annexation of a neighbouring territory, bypassing existing laws. The second bill aims to expedite Russian passport issuance for Ukrainians, waiving fees, residence requirements, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship. These bills are seen as a means to support pro-Russian populations in Ukraine, particularly in Crimea, where many already hold Russian passports. The party's leader, Sergei Mironov, announced the passport fast-track procedure in Sevastopol, accompanied by Russian MPs and celebrities, reflecting Russia's increasing involvement in the region.

The text discusses the decline of the McLaren Formula 1 team, once a dominant force with a rich history of success, including 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' championships, and 8 constructors' titles. The team's struggles began in 2013 with chassis design issues, and now they face problems with the Honda power unit. Despite having world champions like Fernando Alonso, the team's performance has dropped significantly. McLaren's history has been cyclical, with periods of triumph and decline, and they are currently in a similar technological slump as they experienced in the past. The team's leadership, Ron Dennis, is confident that they can turn things around, but their recent performances have been disappointing. The team's reputation and the career of one of its star drivers are at stake, and they are hoping for a resurgence in the near future.

Tommy Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was shot in the head and chest outside Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool. He was found critically injured and later died in hospital. Three men from Liverpool have been arrested in connection with the shooting. Police believe the perpetrators had been waiting outside the nearby Phoenix Gym for about an hour before the incident. A silver VW polo, which fled the scene, is being sought, and police are appealing for witnesses, particularly those captured on CCTV near the market, to come forward.

This passage discusses various ways to celebrate Christmas online, offering a blend of spiritual and modern approaches. It mentions Everyday Church Online, a virtual church service with a global reach, featuring recorded sermons and an interactive chat room. The church's first Christmas theme is Star Wars, relating the franchise to Christian values. The article also highlights Guardians of Ancora, a fantasy game for children, where players embark on Bible-themed quests. Additionally, it showcases creative Nativity videos, like The Digital Story of Nativity, which uses social media elements, and Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle, combining modern and traditional settings. The passage also covers Next Manga's digital efforts, including the Manga Messiah book, available in multiple languages, and the use of social media platforms by Christian groups to engage communities during the festive season.

A hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to acquire 250 hectares of common land for a circuit development, with 320 hectares of replacement land offered. Experts disagree on the potential environmental impact, with some claiming habitat damage and others predicting a biodiversity gain. Natural Resources Wales is neutral, finding it challenging to assess the replacement land's value. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will advise, and the Welsh government will make the final decision on the project's approval.

Chechen Muslim clerics issued a resolution condemning a report by Novaya Gazeta that exposed the detention and killing of homosexuals in Chechnya, deeming it an insult to their faith and Chechen men's dignity. The paper fears this resolution encourages violence against journalists. Over 100 people were detained, and at least three killed, according to the report, which the Russian LGBT Network confirms. Homophobia is prevalent in the Muslim-majority region, and leader Ramzan Kadyrov denies the allegations. The LGBT Network alleges torture of detainees and assists those fleeing persecution, threatening to take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia does not prosecute.

The passage describes a controversial relationship between a company, Investing Solutions, and a charity, Fresh Start Housing, both based in London. Investing Solutions, a large recipient of housing benefit, finds properties for homeless men and makes significant profits by charging multiple housing benefits for one property, while the charity refers clients to them. This practice is criticised by a homeless group and a tenant who experienced poor living conditions. Despite criticism, the company and charity defend their actions, with Fresh Start Housing claiming to have helped hundreds of homeless individuals.

Andrew Lawrence and Ben Gordon led the scoring for GB in a close game against the Netherlands, which ended in a narrow defeat. Coach Joe Prunty was satisfied with the performance, especially from Gordon, who contributed significantly in the third quarter. The team now focuses on the Eurobasket qualifiers, with an emphasis on maintaining intensity throughout.

Conor McGregor, a former five-weight world champion and UFC star, is set to make his boxing debut against Floyd Mayweather in a highly anticipated bout. The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) received a waiver request from McGregor regarding glove size, as Mayweather had previously expressed his intention to use 8oz gloves, which are typically not allowed at the 154 lbs weight class without a waiver. The NAC will debate this matter, considering the health and safety of the fighters as the priority. The fight has sparked controversy, with some boxing personalities criticizing McGregor's involvement, but the NAC's executive director, Bob Bennett, defended the decision, citing McGregor's impressive boxing skills and physical advantages over Mayweather. The NAC has reviewed McGregor's progress and believes he is ready for the fight, and they have also recommended the inclusion of a boxing referee, leading to the hiring of Joe Cortez.

The passage recounts the history of Fleet Street, once the hub of British journalism, and its eventual decline. It was home to the nation's major newspapers, including the first daily newspaper, the Daily Courant. At its peak, Fleet Street was the pinnacle for journalists, with numerous national and regional papers based there. The text highlights the experiences of journalists like Mr. Smith and Mr. Sherriff, who spent decades working on the street, witnessing its vibrant atmosphere and unique culture. However, the move of Rupert Murdoch's newspapers to Wapping in 1986 marked the beginning of Fleet Street's decline, leading to a union dispute and the eventual relocation of most newspapers to other parts of London, embracing computerised printing technology. The passage concludes by reflecting on the end of an era as the last journalists leave Fleet Street, leaving behind a rich history and a significant chapter in British journalism.

J.K. Rowling, the Harry Potter author, received both criticism and support on Twitter for her political views and donations. She faced backlash for her stance on Scottish independence and her donations to political parties, but also found solidarity with some SNP supporters. Rowling's experience highlights the challenges of being a public figure on social media, where she stands up to bullies and abusive comments.

A study by the University of Edinburgh reveals that children from deprived backgrounds are more likely to face police action and engage in violent behaviour compared to those from more affluent families. The research highlights a cycle where poverty increases the risk of violence, and contact with the juvenile justice system exacerbates poverty-related issues. The study also indicates that crime rates in Scotland remain concentrated in poor neighbourhoods, despite an overall decline in crime. This raises concerns about the effectiveness of the Scottish government's efforts to address inequality.

A 25-year-old man, Karl Haugh, was stabbed and killed in a laneway in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh, from Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm and is in custody. Two other men were arrested but released without charge. It is alleged that Walsh, along with two other males, entered the estate and confronted Haugh, leading to a fight where weapons were used. During the altercation, Haugh was stabbed in the back and later pronounced dead at the hospital. The court heard that knives and golf clubs were found at the scene, and a knife with blood on it was recovered. The judge noted tensions in the area and remanded Walsh in custody until August 14th.

In May 2014, Phil Flanagan, a Sinn FÃ©in MLA, tweeted a controversial statement about Tom Elliott, an MP and former member of the UDR. The tweet accused Mr. Elliott of harassment and shooting people during his service in the UDR. Mr. Elliott took legal action, and the High Court heard that the tweet was deleted within an hour of being posted. Mr. Flanagan was required to post an apology on Twitter, admitting that his claims were untrue. The court reserved judgement on compensation, and the insurance firm indemnifying MLAs refused to cover Mr. Flanagan. Mr. Elliott expressed disappointment at the lengthy process but felt vindicated by the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, a historic company with over 230 employees, has boosted its production to 9,500 sweaters weekly to meet increased demand. This surge is attributed to the successful launch of their branded range and the growth of their private label business. The company's managing director, Benny Hartop, expressed optimism about their future, citing dedicated staff and a rise in orders from domestic and international clients.

A 72-year-old lollipop lady, Sylvia Blackburn, suffered severe head injuries after being struck by a car outside a school in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, the driver, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see Mrs. Blackburn, who was wearing visible clothing and escorting a woman and child across the road. Mr. Wright expressed remorse and apologized to the victim's family, acknowledging the impact of the accident. The trial is ongoing at Luton Crown Court, with Mr. Wright denying the charge of causing serious injury by dangerous driving.

The passage describes a military exercise, named "Dynamic Mongoose", conducted by NATO to counter the increasing threat of Russian submarines. The exercise highlights Britain's defence vulnerabilities, particularly the absence of its own maritime patrol aircraft, which has led to a reliance on NATO allies for surveillance. The Russian submarine fleet, with advanced technology and skilled crews, can operate undetected for months, making anti-submarine warfare challenging. NATO's use of underwater drones and long-range patrol aircraft showcases the future of anti-submarine tactics, but also emphasizes the need for international cooperation in addressing these security concerns.

The world's youngest country, South Sudan, is facing a potential genocide and ethnic cleansing crisis as violence spreads across the region. Since July, 340,000 people have fled to neighboring Uganda, surpassing refugee numbers from other countries this year. The conflict, initially between Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer former Vice-President Riek Machar, has now targeted Equatorians, leading to widespread killing, rape, and ethnic-based civilian targeting. Uganda, despite its commendable efforts, is struggling to accommodate the massive refugee influx, with water supply challenges and a growing need for resources. The UNHCR calls for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to end the massacre of civilians.

McKenzie, a former footballer turned professional boxer, will challenge for the English super-middleweight title against Jahmaine Smyle. With a strong boxing pedigree, McKenzie is the son of a former British and European champion and is trained by his uncle, a three-time world champion.

The UK government has allocated funding for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital as part of its nationwide investment in NHS facilities. The new hospital will offer improved patient care with modern amenities, addressing the limitations of the current 1813 building. The project, costing Â£33 million, will be jointly funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new facility will enhance patient experience, provide better working conditions for staff, and contribute to more efficient healthcare delivery in the region. Construction is planned to begin soon, with an expected completion date in autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property in Upperthorpe, Sheffield, an area not usually associated with gun violence. The victim, a local resident, was near his black Mercedes car when the shooting occurred during a family celebration. Armed police responded, and the man was taken to the hospital but succumbed to his injuries. This incident follows a series of recent shootings in Sheffield, including one in Shiregreen, an attack on an elderly couple in Southey Green due to mistaken identity, and two incidents in High Green.

A diverse group of hackers, including the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International, are actively involved in the ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia. These groups engage in various cyber activities, such as releasing official documents, hijacking electronic systems, and conducting DDoS attacks. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have targeted Russian servers and email accounts, while Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, has disrupted Ukrainian government websites and claimed to possess sensitive information. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, has published leaked Kremlin documents and focuses on domestic Russian affairs, with some coverage of Ukraine. The Ukrainian military denies using hacker-obtained data for artillery fire, while media reports suggest otherwise. The activities of these groups significantly impact the conflict, revealing sensitive information and potentially influencing public opinion.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as several MSPs, including Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie, gave their farewell speeches before stepping down ahead of the May 5th election. Mr. Salmond, in his address, reiterated his belief in Scotland's diversity and the need for the parliament to assume more responsibility. He also joked about competing with a major event, likely the UK budget, and wished everyone luck in the election. Duncan McNeil, in his speech, warned that Holyrood should learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, in her farewell, humorously mentioned her interactions with John Swinney.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is seeking input from pensioners and their support networks about their experiences in residential care. This feedback will contribute to a review of the quality of life and care for older individuals in Welsh residential care settings. Ms. Rochira aims to acknowledge both exemplary and substandard care, emphasizing the importance of considering the perspectives of older people and their caregivers. The review will assess various aspects of residents' lives, including their physical and mental health, social connections, and the care home environment. The findings will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies, ensuring a better understanding of the daily realities faced by older people in residential care and driving improvements in the quality of care. However, there is some criticism regarding the absence of a provider expert on the advisory panel, which may limit the review's engagement with the care sector.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based agricultural company, reported a pre-tax profit increase to Â£3.5 million in 2016, despite a slight turnover decrease. International sales grew, particularly in Europe and new markets. The company manufactures animal feeds and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, serving farming communities. Harbro acknowledges the unpredictable nature of agriculture and the challenges posed by Brexit but remains confident in its ability to adapt.

A murder investigation is underway after the body of a man in his 70s was discovered in Little Gaddesden, and a man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are seeking Ian John McLoughlin, a 55-year-old white male with a specific physical description, in connection with the murder. Residents are advised not to approach him and to contact authorities with any relevant information.

David Lipton, the IMF's second-in-command, expressed concerns about the global economy's weakening state, citing China's recent poor trade performance as an indicator. The IMF anticipates a downward revision of its global growth forecast from 3.4%, impacting businesses reliant on China's economic expansion.

The council leader announced that the Cowes ferry crossing would be free until July 2nd to compensate for the issues experienced since its launch. The ferry has faced numerous problems, including breakdowns, groundings, and training issues leading to suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Local businesses have been affected, and compensation for their losses is under discussion. The transport councillor defended the ferry, attributing the issues to teething problems and rectifiable technical faults.

A 32-year-old man died in a multi-vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott on Thursday morning. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested for suspected vehicular manslaughter. The road was closed for several hours while police conducted an investigation.

A London-based temp agency, Matching Models, has sparked controversy with its job advertisements that explicitly request specific physical attributes, such as hair colour, breast size, and overall attractiveness. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners have strongly criticised these ads, deeming them unlawful and demeaning to women. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defends their practices by emphasising the importance of looks to their clients. However, employment lawyer James Lynas highlights the potential legal repercussions, stating that such ads could be seen as discriminatory against older women and could lead to sex discrimination claims. The EHRC is taking action by contacting Matching Models to clarify their hiring practices, while also reminding them of the legal requirements under the 2010 Equality Act, which prohibits discrimination based on various protected characteristics.

A shooting incident at a hostel in Bangalore, India, left one student dead and another injured. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, was arrested after a manhunt. Gun crimes at educational institutions in India are uncommon, and the motive for the shooting is unknown. India has strict gun control laws, but firearms are often used in settling disputes.

The advocacy group Glaad's annual report on LGBT representation in television shows a positive trend with an increase in transgender characters. However, they express concern over the high number of lesbian and bisexual female characters being killed off. The study also highlights a record percentage of black characters, particularly in shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. While progress is acknowledged, Glaad's president emphasizes the need to focus on quality and diversity beyond mere numbers.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has decided not to seek re-election amidst a controversy surrounding a loan to Northampton Town FC. While Mr. Mackintosh was leader of the borough council, the council loaned millions of pounds to the football club for a stadium rebuild and land development, but Â£10.25 million is now unaccounted for. The MP has denied any wrongdoing, but the loan is under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. The local party executive council was set to vote to deselect him, and Mr. Mackintosh has chosen to step down, allowing for a new representative for his constituency.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old policeman, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards by firing into a car full of teenagers. The incident occurred in April in Balch Springs, Dallas, when police responded to reports of underage drinking. Oliver was sacked for policy violations and charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault. If convicted, he would be the first police officer found guilty of murder in Dallas County since 1973. The case has sparked discussions about police accountability, with the Edwards family's lawyer expressing caution despite the indictment.

The passage discusses the decision of Mrs. Trump (Melania Trump) to not immediately move into the White House with her husband, the president-elect, and her son Barron, who will finish the school year at his current school. This has sparked criticism and speculation on social media, as it is unusual for a First Lady not to reside in the White House during her husband's presidency. However, there is historical precedent, and some supporters argue that prioritizing her son's education is a responsible choice. The text also explores the role of the First Lady, which is ceremonial and often involves supporting causes, and how previous First Ladies have balanced their duties with family life. It mentions that Melania Trump's focus on Barron suggests a different approach to the role compared to predecessors like Michelle Obama and Hillary Clinton, and speculates about Ivanka Trump's potential involvement. The article concludes by highlighting how the White House experience can be shaped by the families who inhabit it, with examples of how previous First Families maintained a sense of normalcy.

The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is investigating the initial police response to a 72-year-old man's call, who was later found dead in Inverness. The man died on 27 October, and the Pirc will submit a report on its findings to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service.

The weather service issued a yellow warning for strong winds, with potential gusts up to 75 mph, especially in western mountain regions. The easterly wind direction may exacerbate the impact. Travel disruptions are expected, particularly in specified counties. High winds caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, blocking a main road which is likely to remain closed for clean-up on Monday.

The Giants and the Panthers played a close game, with the Giants taking the lead multiple times but the Panthers equalising. The game ended 4-2 to the Giants. The teams will play again on Saturday in a double-header. Nottingham currently leads the league with 28 points, closely followed by Sheffield and Belfast.

Lewis Hamilton started the race at the back, suffered a broken front wing and did five pit stops. He faces a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races. Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, with a number of collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car. Hamilton was turned into by Felipe Nasr as he avoided Raikkonen's damaged car. At the front, Daniel Ricciardo made a stunning start to take the lead from Nico Rosberg at the first corner, but suffered a puncture on lap three, allowing Rosberg to pass. Rosberg drove off into the distance when the race re-started on lap nine. Hamilton was in the wars, stopped twice under the safety car, and was lying third from last at the restart. He began his fightback from there, but was not able to recover as much ground as the Ferraris.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, publicly came out as homosexual in an interview, aiming to address a neglected topic in German football. His announcement received widespread support from fellow players, football administrators, and public figures, who praised his courage and saw it as a significant step in the fight against homophobia. Hitzlsperger's revelation is considered a landmark moment in Germany, where homophobia in football has been an issue, and it is hoped that it will encourage others to follow suit and foster greater openness regarding sexuality in the sport.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has been instrumental in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League, making 32 Championship appearances this season. With his contract expiring, Sidwell expresses his desire to sign a new deal, citing his impact and performance as reasons for earning another opportunity to play in the Premier League. Brighton's promotion was confirmed with a win over Wigan, and they now aim to secure the league title. Sidwell, who has Premier League experience with multiple clubs, is optimistic about his chances of a new contract.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 in a closely contested match. Blackpool took the lead through Jamille Matt's early strike, but Colchester equalised soon after through Kurtis Guthrie. Both teams had chances to win, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred missing a header and Colchester's Sean Murray being sent off late in the game.

Mark Reid, a 29-year-old defender, has joined Colchester United on a free transfer from Coventry City. With experience in League One and the Championship, Reid is set to bolster Colchester's defence, potentially making his debut in the upcoming EFL Cup match against Aston Villa.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking funds to build a permanent memorial dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of police officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty. The memorial, to be located at the National Memorial Arboretum, will bear the names of over 1,400 individuals and include a brass screen with leaf-shaped cutouts as personal memorials for fallen officers. The recent murder of PC Keith Palmer has emphasised the need for such a tribute, which aims to recognise the contributions and sacrifices of the police service. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019 with a Â£1 million contribution from the government towards its Â£4 million cost.

Manchester United maintain a 15-point lead at the top of the league table with eight games remaining, following a 1-0 victory over Sunderland. Manager Alex Ferguson praises the team's record-breaking 25 wins in the first 30 matches. With a 15-point advantage over Manchester City, United aim to extend their lead in the upcoming derby. Ferguson also discusses injuries sustained in the Sunderland game, including David De Gea's collision, and plans to make changes for the FA Cup replay against Chelsea, considering the fitness of returning players like Wayne Rooney and the availability of Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez. He acknowledges Sunderland's strong performance and attributes United's win to their defensive determination and courage.

Google's chairman, Mr Schmidt, defended the company's tax practices in the UK, stating they paid what was legally required and that tax laws are determined by governments, not companies. Google paid Â£10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, with most of its UK sales routed through Ireland, which has sparked criticism for minimising tax payments in the UK. Margaret Hodge proposed a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, while EU leaders agreed to address tax avoidance through information exchange. The Google chairman advocated for corporate taxes to be levied where economic activity occurs and called for an international tax reform debate, emphasising the need for politicians to set tax rules.

The NHS regulator, NHS Improvement, aims to reduce agency staff spending by Â£1 billion by the end of the financial year, as the NHS has fallen behind schedule in meeting this target. A cap on agency staff rates, introduced in October, has saved Â£600 million, but the NHS is still short of its goal. The cap limits rates to 55% above normal shift rates for all staff except senior managers. The regulator plans to publish league tables ranking trusts by agency spending and collect data on the highest-earning agency staff, as there are concerns about excessive rates, with some hospitals quoted double the intended fees.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a bustling commercial hub, now symbolizes Ireland's economic downturn. Despite recent challenges, local businesses like Matt O'Brien's clothing shop are witnessing a gradual revival. Fianna FÃ¡il criticizes the government's investment choices, advocating for broadband improvement instead of water meters. The government counters with the Center Parcs tourism project, promising job creation. However, local traders call for additional support, including free parking, to further stimulate the economy. The midlands region is showing signs of recovery, but there's a consensus that more government efforts are required.

The tournament involves eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. The competition concludes on 29 May. Key statistics include leading run-scorers Warner (294) and Kohli (267), and leading wicket-takers McClenaghan (9) and Kumar (8). Four England players are participating: Morgan, Buttler, Billings, and Pietersen. The fixtures list is provided, detailing match dates, times, and teams.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs has reported a significant increase in plastic carrier bag usage, with 200 million more bags used since 2013. Many of these bags are non-recyclable and end up in landfills and rivers, posing environmental issues. To address this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags in October, following the successful reduction in bag usage in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where similar charges are in place. Campaigners aim to reduce waste and protect the environment through this initiative.

A severe weather warning for wind caused disruption across Wales, with a school roof damaged, power cuts, and travel delays. The highest winds were recorded in Anglesey, leading to ferry cancellations and train disruptions. The National Trust closed two sites due to expected high winds. The weather eased in the evening, but a blustery forecast prompted the postponement of a Boxing Day event in Rhyl.

Michael B. Jordan is excited to join the cast of Black Panther, directed by Ryan Coogler, and co-starring Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan, who previously worked with Coogler on Creed, is eager to collaborate with them. The film is scheduled for a February 2018 release.

The Alexandra Palace, a historic venue founded in 1875, is undergoing a major restoration project to revitalise its east wing. The project aims to transform the palace into a cultural hub, featuring a theatre for various performances, a cinema, and a comedy and live music venue. The BBC studios will also be refurbished. The Heritage Lottery Fund and Haringey Council are providing significant funding, with additional support from the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust. The theatre, with its original decor and stage machinery, has a rich history of hosting diverse entertainment, including early cinema screenings. The restoration aims to reopen the theatre in 2018, bringing new life to this cultural landmark.

The 30-year-old former Manchester City player, James Milner, had a successful international career with England, earning 61 caps and participating in four major tournaments. Despite his limited playing time at Euro 2016, he holds the record for the most appearances for the England Under-21 team with 46 caps and scored his only international goal during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. Milner's decision to retire from international football was a pragmatic one, and he wished the team well for the future.

Marcy Smith and her family narrowly escaped a devastating house fire in Glovertown, thanks to her son David, who was the only one awake and alerted them to the flames. The fire, started accidentally by burning rubbish in a wood stove, spread rapidly, destroying the house and tragically killing their pets. Despite losing everything, the community's support has been overwhelming, providing the family with essential items. Mrs Smith is incredibly proud of her son's heroic actions, emphasising that his quick thinking saved their lives.

The energy drinks company is rumoured to be interested in purchasing West Ham United for Â£200 million. The club's current owners, Sullivan and Gold, acquired a majority stake in 2010, valuing the club at Â£105 million. They now own over 85% of the club. West Ham's relocation to the London Stadium has sparked further takeover speculation, with interest from Qatari and Chinese investors. Sullivan previously indicated a willingness to sell a minority share to settle debts but expressed a desire to pass on the club's ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards took place in Los Angeles, showcasing fan-voted categories and promoting upcoming summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars dominated with multiple wins, including Best Movie and Best Female Performance for Shailene Woodley. Other notable winners were Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, and Kevin Hart, who gave an emotional acceptance speech. The show featured appearances by various celebrities and previews of highly anticipated films.

Aberdeen loanee Cammy Smith has joined St. Mirren on loan from Dundee United. The 21-year-old has been in good form, scoring five goals this season, including four in 89 appearances for Aberdeen since his debut in 2012. St. Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, expressed his delight with the signing, praising Smith's abilities and maturity. The move provides St. Mirren with an additional attacking option as they prepare to face Falkirk in their upcoming Championship fixture.

Northumberland County Council is taking advantage of the warmer weather to repair potholes using Jetpatcher machines, aiming to fix 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to address drainage issues and clear gutter debris caused by heavy rainfall.

A group of workers, including Steve Innes, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while conducting shutdown work on EnQuest's Thistle platform in December 2016. The incident occurred due to a breakdown in procedures, as the workers were not provided with proper personal protective equipment (PPE). Mr. Innes and his colleagues now face potential health risks, including cancer, and are undergoing blood tests. EnQuest has stated that the exposure levels were below the reportable threshold but still informed the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). The company has taken additional precautionary steps to prevent future incidents. Wood Group, the contractor employing the workers, has prioritized employee safety and conducted medical assessments. The incident has raised concerns about worker treatment and the importance of transparency in ensuring a safe working environment.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a Hindu sculpture for a significant sum, later discovering it was sold by a dealer trafficking in stolen Indian artefacts. The sculpture, believed to be stolen from a temple in India, is being returned after discussions with the Indian government's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ACM acknowledged the dealer's confession of selling looted items, and plans legal action for compensation.

A 4.8-magnitude earthquake hit central Italy, causing widespread tremors but no reported injuries or damage. The quake's epicentre was in Garfagnana, north of Lucca, and its shallow depth led to its impact being felt across a large area, including major cities like Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. This event highlights Italy's seismic vulnerability, with a history of devastating earthquakes, including the 2009 L'Aquila quake that killed almost 300 people. The recent tremor caught experts by surprise, emphasising the challenges in predicting and managing earthquake risks, especially after the controversial convictions of scientists for their role in the 2009 disaster.

A 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, Austin Grant, was initially sceptical about growing fruit in South Yorkshire's climate. However, he recently witnessed a successful harvest, expressing his joy at the sight of the fruit still attached to the plant, awaiting ripeness.

Rockstar has delayed the release of their open-world adventure game, originally scheduled for January 27th, to March 24th, citing the need for additional testing and refinement. Despite the delay, they assure fans that the wait will be worthwhile. In the meantime, Rockstar revealed that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release, showcasing enhanced graphics and performance. The PC version will offer improved visuals, with up to 4K resolution and support for multiple monitors. The minimum PC specifications to run the game have been released. Grand Theft Auto V holds the record for the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1 billion in revenue within three days of its 2013 release.

An elderly artist, aged 76, won the prestigious John Moores Painting Prize for his work 'Squint (19)'. The artist, who had been previously shortlisted and longlisted, expressed his delight at finally winning. The painting, depicting a leper squint in a medieval church, was praised by judge Ansel Krut for its extraordinary and subtle nature. The artist's intention to create a series of paintings, including larger pieces, was also noted. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, has been awarded to renowned artists such as David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked by masked assailants on Thursday morning, resulting in shattered windows and a quickly contained fire at the Yeni Safak building. No casualties were reported, and police are currently searching for the attackers. These incidents follow a similar attack on the pro-government Hurriyet newspaper last September.

A 24-year-old player has been signed by Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer. He previously played for Burton and was on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals. The player will join his new team on 1 January.

Arsene Wenger, Arsenal's manager, has been linked to the England manager role, currently held by interim manager Gareth Southgate. Wenger praises Southgate's experience and observation skills but remains focused on his own job at Arsenal. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to prove his worth for the permanent position. Wenger also addresses transfer speculation, stating that Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract, and provides an injury update on Aaron Ramsey.

A local man fell from a cherry picker while working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road. The incident occurred at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police, in collaboration with the Health and Safety Executive, are conducting an investigation, with the company's full cooperation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had accused Seatruck, the operator of two freight boats, of paying workers less than Â£4 per hour. The new charter will transfer the services back to Serco Northlink, the original operator. Seatruck had argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to their non-UK crew members. Serco Northlink offered to address the pay gap, but Seatruck refused. The new arrangement will ensure that all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage, ending the long-standing issue.

Ken Dickie, 64, passed away in hospital after an incident at a holiday park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, during a visit on May 7th. The argument escalated, leading to a physical confrontation between Mr. Dickie and Mr. Mitchell outside the park bar. Mr. Mitchell and his mother were found guilty of attempting to pervert the course of justice by providing false accounts of the incident to the police. Mr. Mitchell also pleaded guilty to common assault. The pair will be sentenced on February 6th.

Rod Temperton, a renowned British songwriter and musician, passed away at 66 in London due to cancer. Known for his work with Michael Jackson, Heatwave, and other artists, Temperton's songs achieved global success. He wrote hits like "Thriller," "Off the Wall," and "Boogie Nights," and his talent was recognized with a Grammy Award and Oscar nominations. Despite his significant impact, Temperton maintained a low profile, earning him the nickname "The Invisible Man." His death prompted tributes from industry peers, highlighting his genius and the lasting impact of his music.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader and Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, has discovered ancient earthworks in the western Brazilian Amazon, estimated to be around 2,000 years old. The investigation focused on ditched enclosures, now revealed due to modern deforestation, which were previously hidden by rainforest. Over 450 large geometrical structures, known as "geoglyphs," were found. The purpose of these sites is still a mystery, but they are not believed to be villages or defensive structures due to the lack of artefacts and their layout. Dr. Loader's analysis of soil samples suggests the geoglyphs were constructed within tall vegetation, unlike other ritual sites, and were likely not visible above the forest canopy. The research challenges previous assumptions about the Amazonian forests, indicating human influence through the artificial gathering of diverse plant species over millennia. The team compares the ancient practices to a "prehistoric supermarket" and suggests that modern biodiversity in the region may still reflect these early agroforestry techniques.

Nick Kyrgios, the 21-year-old Australian tennis player, defeated Sam Querrey in a swift 53-minute match to advance to the second round. Kyrgios, currently ranked 12th in the world, is on the rise after winning the Japan Open. He attributed his unusually quiet demeanour during the match to fatigue from his recent success and travel to Shanghai. This is in contrast to his behaviour at the Shanghai Masters the previous year, where he was fined for an outburst.

The HPV vaccine, currently administered to girls aged 12 and 13 to prevent cervical cancer, is advocated by scientists and charities to also protect against head and neck cancers. These groups are urging the Welsh government to extend the vaccination program to boys, citing the rising cases of head and neck cancers and the significant role of HPV in global cancer cases. The Welsh government has stated they will await advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old cancer patient, passed away from a rare blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He gained attention for his positive attitude and documented his journey on social media, attracting over 28,000 followers. Jak briefly attended a school prom in his honour but had to leave due to illness. His story inspired many, and his family continues to raise funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

Egypt secured a late 1-0 win over Uganda in a tight and uneventful game. Mohamed Salah provided the assist for Abdallah El Said's winning goal in the 89th minute. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside and failed to register a shot on target. The result eliminates Uganda and sets up a crucial final group game between Egypt and Ghana for the top spot in Group D.

The Lancashire County Council plans to develop a new railway station in Skelmersdale, a town in the north-west of England, which has been without a station since 1956. The council has identified land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College as the preferred site, with the potential for future expansion. This decision follows a study by Network Rail, and the council aims to provide direct train services to Liverpool. The project is seen as a significant development for the town's transport infrastructure.
A man in his late 40s was arrested after police discovered an elaborate grow house containing plants during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish-German origin was found with severe injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony. She was dragged by the neck through multiple streets, and the suspect, her 38-year-old ex-partner, later turned himself in to the authorities. The motive for the attack is still unknown, and police are appealing for witnesses to assist in the investigation.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin has found that women are just as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are 25% less likely to receive one when they do. This research challenges the 'reticent female' theory, as it found no evidence that women are more hesitant to ask for salary increases due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from gender stereotypes. The study analysed 4,600 full-time and part-time workers, controlling for various factors, and concluded that there may be an element of pure discrimination against women. Interestingly, the study also noted that younger women and men under 40 are negotiating pay more successfully, indicating a potential shift in negotiating behaviour.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site to accommodate the growing need for cemetery space. While two existing cemeteries have some availability, they are expected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021. The council has invested in ground investigations to identify potential sites, but no suitable locations have been found due to various constraints such as size, ground conditions, water table levels, and land covenants. With limited options, the council is exploring other possibilities, but the challenge of finding new burial sites mirrors the difficulties faced in finding new housing sites within Oxford.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, or HebCelt, is introducing an augmented reality app for visitors to access additional content during the event. The app will allow users to scan items like signs and posters to unlock online information, including videos and band interviews, enhancing the festival experience. This year's festival, held in Stornoway from July 19th to 22nd, features artists such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. The app aims to provide an interactive experience for attendees and also allow global audiences to engage with the festival remotely, accessing content and capturing the festival's atmosphere.

The 10-year-old racehorse Many Clouds, bred in Ireland, suffered a fatal collapse after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. Veterinary staff confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare occurrence in racehorses. Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia, causing overheating, but no significant underlying health issues were known. Despite this, questions remain as to whether this condition contributed to his death.

A 34-year-old individual, previously known as David Ayrton and now called Davina, has been found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in 2004. The defendant met the victim in a Portsmouth garage and committed the assault while two others were asleep. The victim's recollection of the event was clear, and she reported the attack to a care home worker in 2014. The defendant, who has learning difficulties and has attempted suicide, will be sentenced on March 4th and remanded in a male prison due to concerns for their safety and the risk of not appearing for sentencing. The trial was described as unusual by the judge.

Novak Djokovic and his partner, Nenad Zimonjic, lost in the men's doubles tennis at the Rio Olympics. This defeat followed Djokovic's earlier singles loss to Juan Martin del Potro. The Serbian's recent form has been inconsistent, with an unexpected early exit at Wimbledon but a subsequent Masters title win in Toronto.

Over 20 competitors will participate in a chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, on Saturday. Participants from various countries will use chainsaws to sculpt animal and human figures from logs. The reigning champion, Pete Bowsher, will compete to retain his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, is recovering from a foot injury sustained in September during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy. He is nearing a return to action, aiming to be fit for the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb is currently in a pre-season training phase and is optimistic about his progress. He has set a target to return at the beginning of February, although he hopes to expedite his comeback by a couple of weeks. Webb has strong ties to his home region, having renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, despite receiving offers from other clubs. He made his debut with Ospreys in 2007 and is committed to representing his country, Wales.

Two men were stopped by US border agents near Sumas, Washington, on Tuesday, with one of them firing a weapon and fleeing. The incident led to the arrest of four individuals involved in a drug smuggling operation from Canada to San Francisco. The men were carrying backpacks containing a large quantity of MDMA (ecstasy), and a third man, a Canadian citizen, was arrested in British Columbia. A woman and her boyfriend were also arrested for their involvement in the plan. The area is known for smuggling activities, and the defendants face conspiracy and drug-related charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse and cyberbullying, with over 4,500 cases in the past year. The charity emphasizes the severe impact of online trolls on children's mental health and well-being, with some as young as seven experiencing torment and fear. Dame Esther Rantzen highlights the need for adult intervention and school involvement to address this growing issue. The report, released during Anti-Bullying Week, also includes advice from young people on coping with bullying.

The US's decision to abstain from vetoing a UN resolution condemning Israeli settlements has caused tension between the two allies. The resolution, which passed on Friday, calls for an end to settlement construction, considering it illegal under international law. This move angered Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the US of drafting and pushing for the resolution. In response, Netanyahu summoned US and UN ambassadors, recalled Israeli ambassadors, and took other diplomatic actions. The Jerusalem Planning Committee postponed a vote on new settlement homes, citing a request from Netanyahu's office to avoid further conflict with the US ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry is expected to address the Israeli government's criticism of the Obama administration and present his vision for peace. Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as a positive step towards the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

The passage describes the celebrations and tributes for Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, including a BBC interview with Prince William praising the Queen's dedication to duty and service. The Queen's visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and the release of commemorative stamps featuring the Royal Family are highlighted. The text also mentions the criticism Prince William has faced regarding his royal duties and his response to it, as well as the plans for the Queen's birthday celebrations and the ongoing debate about the media's coverage of the royal family.

West Ham United, a Premier League team, defeated Cheltenham Town from League Two 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored quick goals before halftime, securing the win. Cheltenham had some chances but couldn't convert, and West Ham could've increased their lead if not for a goal-line clearance and a good save. The result eliminated League Two's presence in the competition before the third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, was killed in a motorcycle collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. The driver, Andreas Werner, failed to see McNicholl and turned his vehicle, causing the fatal crash. Werner pleaded guilty to careless driving and was fined and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not wish for Werner to be imprisoned, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse in judgement.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist who gained notoriety in Syria through online propaganda, returned to the UK and was arrested. He was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State-affiliated group known for sophisticated recruitment tactics targeting young British Muslims. Khawaja's activities in Syria included creating propaganda, soliciting donations, and participating in violent acts, as evidenced by a gruesome photo. He attempted to re-enter the UK secretly, but was arrested and faces life imprisonment. The police consider him highly dangerous, and his motives for returning remain unclear.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old forward, has joined Barnsley from Wrexham, where he scored four goals in 36 appearances last season. Barnsley's caretaker manager, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and ability to trouble defenders, which aligns with the team's playing style. This transfer marks Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season, announced ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley.

Numerous bottles of detergent, believed to be from a lost shipping container, have washed up on beaches in Cornwall, UK. The National Trust and other organisations are working to clear the bottles, which may pose a risk to wildlife. While the source of the bottles is suspected to be from a known lost container of 'Vanish' detergent, there is currently no concrete evidence to confirm this.

A crash on the A9 in Caithness resulted in one person being taken to hospital with serious injuries and several others sustaining minor injuries. The incident led to a road closure, with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich route. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers after helping the club secure promotion to the Championship. Dervite made 14 appearances last season and has been a consistent performer since joining Bolton in 2014, making 83 appearances in total. His contract renewal follows those of several other key players, ensuring a strong squad for the upcoming Championship campaign.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour have a history of forming alliances to challenge the government on various issues, including Brexit and other legislative matters. However, tensions arose when the Lib Dems insisted on amendments regarding EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for Brexit, while Labour deferred to the Commons. The Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding to the government and building false hope, while Labour criticised the Lib Dems for grandstanding and creating campaign material. Despite these differences, both parties expressed a willingness to continue working together on shared issues, albeit with some residual tensions.

The passage discusses the low priority given to defence in the UK's political landscape, despite growing global instability. The UK's military interventions and public fatigue contribute to this trend. The article highlights the reduced defence spending and military capabilities, with potential consequences for NATO relations and US perceptions. It mentions the upcoming election's lack of focus on defence, with parties offering limited details. The text also covers the debate around nuclear deterrence, with varying party stances, and the challenges of maintaining a credible military force.

Barcelona has made a voluntary tax payment of â¬13.5 million regarding the signing of Neymar, despite denying any tax-related crime. This payment was made to cover potential interpretations of the contracts involved in the transfer, which has been under investigation. The club initially paid Â£48.6 million for Neymar, but the total cost, including various fees, is estimated at Â£106.8 million. The investigation follows the resignation of former president Sandro Rosell, who is also being investigated for alleged misappropriation of funds.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old passenger in a van, was killed in a collision with a car driven by Albert Newman, who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Mr. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for retired individuals, citing concerns about their driving abilities. The family mourns Mr. Luciw's tragic death, emphasizing his young age and the loss of future milestones with his baby daughter. They believe stricter driving assessments for older drivers could prevent similar accidents. The van driver, Andy Harrington, also supports medical examinations for retired drivers. Currently, UK drivers over 70 renew their licenses every three years with a self-assessment form, but no medical or driving test is required. The DVLA maintains that evidence does not indicate older drivers are more prone to causing serious accidents and that they have procedures to remove driving entitlement for those with medical conditions. Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older drivers to maintain their independence.

A group of women who suffered severe side effects from transvaginal mesh implants have raised concerns about the safety of the procedure. An independent review was conducted, but two patient representatives on the review panel resigned due to disagreements with the final report, which they believed was watered down. Professor Alison Britton will now examine the review process and its conclusions. The report recommended against routine use of the implants for pelvic organ prolapse and emphasized the need for informed consent and mandatory adverse event reporting. Despite calls for a ban, the health secretary stated that the government does not have the authority to do so, as it falls under the jurisdiction of the UK regulatory body. The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for not reaching a consensus among panel members and faced criticism from affected women. Two other patient representatives and a consultant also resigned due to dissatisfaction with the final report. Over 20,000 Scottish women have received mesh or tape implants, and more than 400 are taking legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes and 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially questioned the validity of the record due to the nature of the race, as Muir was the only competitor in the 5K event, but British Athletics confirmed that the time is expected to be ratified as an official record. McColgan praised Muir's talent, suggesting she has the potential to win world medals and improve her 5K time even further.

Jung, riding Sam, won the competition, with Astier Nicolas and Phillip Dutton claiming silver and bronze respectively. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, finished 12th despite a strong show-jumping performance, due to time penalties in the cross-country phase. The article also promotes fan engagement with equestrian sports during the Rio Olympics, offering a guide and newsletter subscription.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old British tennis player, defeated Fabio Fognini in a tense and dramatic match at Wimbledon, securing a spot in the fourth round. The match lasted over two hours, with Murray winning in four sets. Fognini, the 29th seed, had opportunities to force a fifth set but Murray's resilience and a late surge secured the victory. The match was characterized by Fognini's fluctuating performance, an ankle injury, and on-court tensions. Murray will next face Benoit Paire, while fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week.

Paramedics and police were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven following a sudden death, where they found evidence of alcohol being served outside of licensing hours. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside of permitted hours. The court heard that licensing laws in Dungiven were not always followed, and the judge expressed concern over Ms O'Neill's previous record, fining her Â£3,000 and ordering the bar's closure for three months.
