Paul Merson, a Sky Sports pundit, criticised Andros Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, questioning his ability. However, Townsend proved Merson wrong by scoring a brilliant goal for England against Italy. Merson acknowledged his mistake and praised Townsend. Despite this, Merson reignited the debate after Townsend's brief appearance for Tottenham against Burnley, prompting a response from Townsend on Twitter.

Chelsea have made an offer to sign 22-year-old Japanese forward Yoshinori Muto from FC Tokyo. If the transfer is successful, Muto will initially join Chelsea's partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, on loan. The player has expressed his honour at receiving the offer but is yet to make a decision. Muto, a recent economics graduate, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he completes the move. The transfer fee is rumoured to be around Â£4 million. Chelsea's interest in Muto is not linked to their recent sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale study has discovered that babies who receive antibiotics during the first six months of their lives are more likely to become overweight as toddlers. This finding mirrors the use of antibiotics in farm animals to promote weight gain, suggesting a potential link between antibiotics and childhood obesity. The study, published in Pediatrics, compared the weight and height of 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with antibiotic prescription records, revealing that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by age two. Repeated antibiotic prescriptions before age two further increased the likelihood of being overweight. The study's lead author, Dr. Antti Saari, cautioned that antibiotic exposure before six months of age or repeatedly during infancy may contribute to the global childhood obesity epidemic, emphasizing the need for judicious antibiotic use in infancy.

A member of the Queen's Guard at Buckingham Palace suffered an embarrassing moment when he slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony. The incident was captured on camera by a tourist, showing the guard falling and dropping his rifle. The guard quickly recovered and continued the ceremony, but not before realizing the large crowd witnessing his mishap. The event occurred due to the metal protectors on his boot soles, causing him to lose footing on the manhole cover.

The iconic TV miniseries "Roots," which captivated over 100 million viewers in 1977, is being remade by A&E networks for a 2016 release. The new version will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, and will closely follow Alex Haley's novel, with added input from African and African-American history scholars. The remake aims to introduce the powerful story of Kunta Kinte, an African slave, to a new generation, while also appealing to fans of the original. LeVar Burton, the original Kinte, will co-executive produce, emphasizing the enduring relevance of the story in light of recent racial milestones and tensions in America.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has accused palace aides at Clarence House of attempting to force him into an orgy in 1978. Lawler claims he was groped and pinned to a chair by a male staff member on his first day of work, leading him to quit immediately. Despite reporting the incident to palace officials last year, Lawler alleges his complaints were initially ignored. The police are now investigating the claims, and a retired royal aide has been interviewed but denied involvement. The Palace has assured Lawler of their cooperation with the police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, creatively announced their pregnancy through a rap video set to the theme of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video, which has gone viral with over 1.7 million views on YouTube, showcases the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood. They reveal that they are expecting a child and share a sonogram at the end. The Meeks' video is a playful take on the original song, replacing the story of Will Smith's character with their own experience of family pressure and the surprise of a quick conception. The couple was surprised by the video's success, which was initially intended to inform distant loved ones about their pregnancy.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in the iconic 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at an auction in Beverly Hills. The auction included over 150 items from the Academy Award-winning film, including the dress, which was a jacket and full skirt ensemble worn in several significant scenes. The outfit has faded over time from its original slate blue-gray colour to light gray. It was part of James Tumblin's extensive private collection, who acquired it in the 1960s for $20. Tumblin was a dedicated collector of Hollywood memorabilia, including costumes and props from Gone With the Wind. The auction also featured other notable items, such as a straw hat worn by Leigh and clothing worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler. Gone With the Wind, celebrated for its 75th anniversary, was adapted from Margaret Mitchell's book and featured Hattie McDaniel, who made history as the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents allegedly dangled him over the edge. The child was rescued by his parents and suffered minor injuries. Zoo officials and eyewitnesses believe the parents put the child in danger, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed after the incident.

A speed camera, previously used to monitor a 30mph zone in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been re-angled to face a residential house. The camera, along with around 300 others in the West Midlands, has been non-operational for over two years due to outdated technology. Birmingham City Council is aware of the re-positioned camera and will send an engineer to investigate, potentially removing it. The camera will not be included in a new pilot scheme for digital technology cameras.

Usain Bolt, the six-time Olympic gold medallist, will represent Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2nd and 3rd. Bolt expressed his excitement, noting Jamaica's strong relay tradition and his commitment to representing his country proudly. The Jamaican team list for the event will be revealed soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, along with Neymar's sister Rafaella, demonstrated their commitment to Barcelona by attending a basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid, known as El Clasico. Barcelona won the Euro League contest 85-80. Despite the victory, Real Madrid maintains a slight lead in the Euro League standings. Neymar also played a crucial role in Brazil's 1-0 win over Chile, enduring rough challenges from their opponents. With the international break over, Neymar and Barcelona aim to continue their La Liga success, aiming for a treble of trophies, starting with their upcoming match against Celta Vigo.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with over 8,480 rescued between Friday and Monday. The Italian Coast Guard received numerous distress calls, but the exact number of missing migrants is uncertain. The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reports that Italy has seen over 10,000 migrant arrivals in the first quarter of 2015, with many originating from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, and using Libya as a transit point. The dangerous journey has led to the deaths of at least 480 migrants due to various factors, including bad weather and smuggler practices.

Alexis Sanchez, a highly sought-after forward, chose to join Arsenal and their manager Arsene Wenger over Liverpool, despite the latter's interest. Sanchez has been a success at Arsenal, scoring 19 goals and impressing with his adaptability and all-around game. Wenger is pleased with Sanchez's decision and attributes it to the player's belief in his management. The Arsenal boss also praises Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for his team's development, despite recent setbacks.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a renowned British cyclist with an impressive Olympic and Tour de France record, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at the London Olympic Velodrome. The hour record, a prestigious feat in cycling, has recently regained popularity due to reformed regulations. Wiggins, motivated by the challenge, aims to inspire others to take up cycling. He will compete against the current record held by Australian Rohan Dennis, who cycled 52.491km in an hour. The event is expected to attract a large crowd and will be broadcast live, with tickets on sale from April 19.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, admitted that her challenging match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup was an 'eye-opener' for the upcoming claycourt season. Despite winning, Williams felt unprepared for the clay surface, having to adjust her game from hard courts. The match highlighted the need for Williams to adapt her strategy for clay, where rallies and longer points are more common. The US team suffered a 3-2 defeat overall, with Williams and Alison Riske losing the doubles rubber, resulting in their relegation to World Group II.

River Plate, an Argentine football club, expresses interest in re-signing their former striker, Radamel Falcao, who is currently on loan at Manchester United from Monaco. Falcao, a 29-year-old Colombian forward, struggled during his loan spell at United, scoring only four Premier League goals. However, he recently equalled Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, publicly stated their desire to bring Falcao back, acknowledging the player's history with the club, where he scored 34 goals in 90 appearances before leaving for Porto in 2009.

Ella Henderson, known for her vocals and appearance on The X Factor, has been announced as the face of dry shampoo brand Batiste's 2015 campaign, 'Ready For It'. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles, marking her first brand collaboration. The partnership highlights Henderson's excitement as a regular user of the product and Batiste's CEO's enthusiasm for the natural fit between the artist and the brand.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who shot and killed Aaron Siler, has caused outrage among Siler's family and friends. The billboard, funded by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, was intended to thank the community for their support following the shooting. However, Siler's loved ones find it disrespectful and want it removed, feeling it glorifies the officer's actions. The incident has sparked controversy, with the police association claiming no offence was intended, while the investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in a clash with militants near the Pakistan border. The militants, belonging to the group Jaish al Adal, crossed into Iran from Pakistan and have claimed responsibility for the attack. Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to capture the surviving attackers, and Pakistan has condemned the incident, promising to investigate and apprehend the militants if they are found within their borders.

The Japanese government has confirmed that its Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani assured the Diet that fighter jets are scrambled to investigate unidentified flying objects that could pose a threat to Japan's airspace, but no alien spacecraft have been identified. This response was prompted by a query from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who has a history of political stunts and claims to have seen a UFO. The discussion highlights Japan's engagement with potential extraterrestrial threats and the country's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on broke and shattered. The incident occurred at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China, when Jin Pai stood on the rim of the toilet, concerned about its cleanliness. The porcelain toilet tipped over, causing the injuries. Jin Pai initially called his travelling companions for help, too embarrassed to shout, but authorities and emergency personnel arrived and transported him to a local hospital. He received several dozen stitches. Jin Pai later changed his story to the police, claiming he was sitting when the toilet broke, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities ruled the incident an accident, reminding people that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a girl over four years and filming her and others with a hidden camera in her bathroom. The investigation started when the 15-year-old victim discovered the camera, leading to charges of aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse, and invasion of privacy. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims, including the 15-year-old since she was nine. The police chief emphasized the disturbing nature of the crime, and Rebbie is currently held on a substantial bail amount.

Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama has created a unique series of photographs, showcasing fathers leaping energetically into the air next to their po-faced daughters. The images, featured in Aoyama's book "Daughter and Salary Man," offer a playful twist on traditional father-daughter portraits, allowing fathers to express their fun side. The photographs have gained online attention for their creative concept, with the fathers' suits and various Japanese backdrops adding to the visual interest.

The recent dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director has sparked discussions about the upcoming county championship season and Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, is now in a position to make a comeback after Downton's sacking. The 34-year-old batsman was in a reflective mood during the Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval, but also shared jokes with teammates and photographers. With England aiming to reclaim the Ashes, Pietersen's return to Surrey is a significant step towards his international comeback.

Relegation-battling Romanian side Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt have dismissed Brazilian manager Ze Maria for the second time in seven days. The former Brazil international was initially fired on Wednesday but was reinstated the following day by the club's owner, Angelo Massone. However, after a 2-0 defeat to FC Botosani, Ze Maria was sacked again, with the team six points from safety in 16th place.

Radamel Falcao's former teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United, despite his unhappiness in France. Falcao's performance at United has been underwhelming, scoring only four goals, which may result in the club opting against making the transfer permanent. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League, but acknowledges that Falcao may have sought a more vibrant atmosphere.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy, taking the till and approximately $1500 in cash. The offender, described as very tall, was captured on security footage and is still at large. Police are appealing to the public for any information that could help identify the man, who demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for the second time on Monday, accused of having sexual relationships with underage students. The initial arrest occurred on March 19, when she admitted to kissing and allowing a 15-year-old student to touch her breasts. After her release on bail, another 15-year-old student came forward, alleging sexual encounters with Granado on consecutive nights in January. The second arrest was made based on these new claims, and she was released again after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district has placed Granado on administrative leave, ensuring she has no contact with students during the investigation.

A video of a crocodile with a pet dog in its jaws has gone viral, shocking viewers. The incident occurred in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, where a tourist witnessed the crocodile attack and capture the dog, belonging to a local shop owner. The crocodile's presence in a public marina highlights the proximity of these creatures to humans due to urbanisation. Social media reactions express horror and dislike towards crocodiles.

Steve Bruce, despite Hull City's 2-0 loss to Southampton, remains confident about avoiding relegation from the Premier League. Hull's target of 10 wins for survival seems unlikely, but Bruce believes 8 or 9 wins might be sufficient. Hull's recent struggles are attributed to long-term injuries to key players, but Bruce highlights their positive recent history and remains optimistic about their survival. Southampton's victory, aided by a James Ward-Prowse penalty, moved them to fifth in the table, but manager Ronald Koeman faced an issue with Sadio Mane attempting to take a penalty against team rules.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from teaching for at least two years after allowing and making changes to his students' SATs exam answers, which led to the invalidation of the entire school's results. Guffick admitted to altering some answers himself and asking students to make changes, although he claimed it was to improve legibility. The Department for Education annulled the school's results after an investigation, and a conduct panel found his actions to be dishonest but not fraudulent. Guffick was remorseful and cooperative during the investigation, but his actions were deemed deliberate and unacceptable, resulting in a prohibition order from teaching.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish footballer, married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year. Despite limited playing time at Manchester United, Lindegaard shared a photo with his wife on Instagram, enjoying the English weather. The couple has a son and has been together since 2012. Beqiri, of Albanian descent, is an active Instagram user with over 17,000 followers, often sharing modelling photos. Lindegaard's football career has been challenging, with few appearances and being third-choice goalkeeper at United. Despite his professional struggles, he seems to be enjoying personal success with his family.

The iconic blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium in the Bronx failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction. Owned by baseball legend Reggie Jackson, the 13 letters, each 10 feet tall, were expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000. However, there were no bids, despite Jackson's hope for a new owner. The letters, installed in 1976, hold historical significance for the Yankees and New York City. Interestingly, a Mets bullpen car from the 1960s exceeded its estimated value, selling for $112,500.

Brendan Rodgers, Liverpool manager, addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe's recent controversies, emphasizing their professional obligations. Despite the incidents, Rodgers chose not to discipline the players, focusing on their upcoming FA Cup semi-final. He highlighted the challenges young athletes face in managing public perception. Rodgers also discussed Steven Gerrard's availability but remained tight-lipped about his starting lineup decisions.

Mesut Ozil, the Arsenal playmaker, shared a glimpse of his downtime at home with his dog after an impressive performance in Germany's Euro 2016 qualifier win against Georgia. Ozil, who missed Arsenal's previous game due to illness, is expected to start against Liverpool. He has been in good form since returning from injury, adapting well to the demands of English football with several assists and goals.

Barcelona's president, Josep Maria Bartomeu, has confirmed that the club is not looking to replace manager Luis Enrique, despite recent speculation. Enrique, who joined the club last summer on a two-year contract, has led the team to a successful season, with the potential to win three trophies. Bartomeu praised Enrique's work ethic and focus, and stated that the club is happy with his performance, especially given their current position in La Liga and the Champions League.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract worth around Â£100,000 per week until 2020, following impressive performances under manager Brendan Rodgers. Henderson's contract extension comes after similar agreements from teammates Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. The 24-year-old midfielder, signed by Liverpool in 2011, is expected to be a candidate for the club captaincy when Steven Gerrard leaves. Liverpool aims to secure more players, while negotiations with Raheem Sterling are anticipated to restart in the summer.

Filipe Luis, the Brazilian left-back, reaffirms his commitment to Chelsea, dismissing Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Despite a challenging season at Stamford Bridge, Luis expresses his desire to honour his three-year contract, citing his happiness at the club. With the Premier League title race intensifying, Luis acknowledges the difficulty of the remaining fixtures but believes Chelsea is prepared under the guidance of manager Jose Mourinho.

Nathan Hughes, a rugby player for Wasps, had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after accidentally knocking out George North. The initial ban was criticised by many, including fellow players and former England player Austin Healey, who called it a 'joke'. The appeal panel reviewed new evidence and ruled that the incident was accidental, allowing Hughes to return to action immediately.

A stunning sunset with deep red hues was observed in Washington, captivating Seattle resident Tim Durkan, who captured aerial photos. The intense colors were caused by wildfires in Siberia, where farmers' grass-burning activities led to uncontrollable flames due to strong winds. The resulting smoke, carried by atmospheric winds, reached the Pacific Northwest, creating a unique atmospheric phenomenon. The red color was intensified by smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange hues to dominate during sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke clears, the sunsets will gradually return to their normal appearance.

A Missouri woman, Becky Schoenig, had her new car stolen, but it was later recovered by police after a tip-off. The car was returned with some unexpected modifications, including red rims and detailing. Rather than being upset, Schoenig took it in her stride, thanking the thieves on Facebook for 'pimping out' her car. However, the car required professional cleaning due to cigarette and marijuana smells. Schoenig is also honouring the man who helped locate her car by creating a special smoothie named after him at her restaurant.

Manchester City players face a significant financial loss of Â£500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to secure a Champions League spot for the upcoming season. This incentive is part of the club's strategy to comply with financial fair play regulations, with star players on incentivised contracts. Currently in fourth place, a recent loss to rivals Manchester United has put their European qualification hopes at risk. The top three Premier League teams automatically qualify, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. The team's recent poor form, with seven losses and early exits from other competitions, has left their manager, Manuel Pellegrini, acknowledging the need for improvement. The financial implications extend to the potential difficulty in signing top players like Paul Pogba, who is also sought after by Manchester United.

In a match between the Under 18s of Manchester United and Manchester City, United won 1-0 thanks to a free-kick from Callum Gribbin. The game, played at Altrincham's Moss Lane, featured a high proportion of English and local players. United's victory puts them two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City have now lost both of their end-of-season play-off matches. The match showcased the talent of young players on both sides, with several players impressing and potentially deserving future first-team opportunities.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised his Italian counterpart, Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap in the 1-1 draw between England and Italy. Hart, who reached his own milestone of 50 caps, expressed his admiration for Buffon's longevity and achievements, considering him an inspiration at 37 years old. The younger Hart, celebrating his achievement at the Juventus Stadium, aims to continue representing his country and learning from veteran goalkeepers like Buffon.

Chipotle, a popular Mexican restaurant chain, is entering the food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery services in 67 cities. This move comes as Chipotle aims to capitalize on the growing demand for food delivery, estimated to be a $70 billion market. Customers will incur a nine per cent service charge, in addition to delivery fees starting at $5, for the convenience of having burritos and other menu items delivered to their homes. Chipotle's decision to collaborate with Postmates, which operates similarly to Uber with independent contractors, follows the company's previous rejections of similar offers from other third-party delivery services. The restaurant's popularity is highlighted by recent visits from presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton, who were spotted at Chipotle locations. Other major food chains, such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, are also exploring or have already launched their own delivery services to compete in this expanding market.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have written an opinion piece in The Boston Globe, pleading for the death penalty to be removed as an option for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. The parents, Bill and Denise Richard, who also had a daughter severely injured in the attack, express their understanding of the severity of the crimes but argue that pursuing the death penalty will prolong their anguish through years of appeals. They propose a life sentence without the possibility of release or appeal as an alternative, hoping to bring closure to the case and spare their remaining children from further pain.

A billionaire has transformed a Boeing 747 into a luxurious private residence, costing approximately Â£400 million. The customised jet features bedrooms, lounges, a dining room, kitchen, and even an onboard restaurant. This unique conversion provides the owner with a lavish living space, accommodating guests in style and comfort during flights.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket with an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft towards the International Space Station, aiming to land the rocket stage on a floating barge. Despite a successful launch, the landing attempt was unsuccessful as the rocket tipped over. SpaceX's goal is to reduce space access costs by reusing rockets, with this mission being their sixth to the ISS. The Dragon carries supplies, including an espresso maker, and will return with science experiments and trash.

Priscilla Presley, former wife of Elvis Presley, is set to witness the first wedding at a new Las Vegas chapel dedicated to Elvis. The wedding is part of a contest organised by NBC's Today show, offering an Elvis-themed wedding experience to one lucky couple. The wedding will take place at the Westgate Hotel, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed numerous sold-out shows. The winning couple will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfares, and tickets to an Elvis theatre show. Priscilla emphasised the chapel's authenticity, stating it is a first-class experience and not a joke. Couples must submit videos or photos with a description to enter the contest, with the winner announced next Monday.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, believes his team has a chance to overtake Manchester City in the Premier League title race. Despite a demanding season, Liverpool remains in contention after a crucial 2-0 victory over Newcastle United, with Henderson and Simon Mignolet reaching 47 appearances this season. Liverpool's recent dip in form against Manchester United and Arsenal hasn't deterred Henderson, who remains optimistic about catching City, who are four points ahead after a loss to Manchester United. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen's goals secured the win against Newcastle, with Allen acknowledging the importance of the result after recent setbacks.

Roma secured a crucial win against Napoli in Serie A, ending their home winless streak and boosting their Champions League qualification hopes. Miralem Pjanic's first-half goal and Morgan de Sanctis' impressive goalkeeping secured the victory. The win moved Roma four points clear of Lazio, while Napoli's struggles continued with a fifth consecutive winless game. The match was significant due to heightened security measures following a fan's death in a shooting incident last season.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played out a dull 0-0 draw in League One, offering little excitement for fans. The match highlights were comically brief, lasting only 27 seconds, reflecting the lack of noteworthy action.

A man, Roland Giroux, has developed a unique bond with his pet fish, a blood parrot cichlid. Despite the common belief that marine pets lack interactive abilities, Giroux demonstrates an extraordinary connection by gently massaging the fish in its tank. The fish responds positively, initially moving away but then returning to enjoy the sensation of being stroked. Giroux's frequent interactions, including hand-feeding and petting, have made the fish more sociable, even seeking out his touch. This behaviour is unusual, as blood parrot cichlids are hybrids, not typically known for such social behaviour.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery temperament, has returned to the England cricket team after a tumultuous year. His passion and aggression are seen as valuable assets, but must be carefully managed to avoid negative consequences. Stokes' natural exuberance and willingness to confront opponents are admired, but he must channel his aggression productively. England aims to strike a balance between harnessing his potential and maintaining discipline, ensuring his aggression translates into runs and wickets.

Wales' crucial Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium, with both teams vying for the top spot in Group B, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. The match, taking place at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12, holds significant importance as Wales aims to qualify for a major tournament for the first time since 1958. Despite Belgium's higher world ranking, Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has boosted their confidence and raised expectations of securing an automatic qualifying spot for the 2016 finals in France. The Football Association of Wales confirmed the sell-out due to overwhelming demand, with the team preferring the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium over the larger Millennium Stadium, adhering to UEFA's venue change regulations.

England's Under-17 football team, the defending champions, will compete in the upcoming UEFA European Championship in Bulgaria. Coach John Peacock has announced the squad, featuring players from various Premier League clubs. The team has a strong record, having qualified with a 100% win rate. They are placed in Group D and will face Italy, Holland, and the Republic of Ireland, with their opening match against Italy on May 7. The squad includes Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and a recalled Liverpool duo, Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.

Manchester City are interested in signing young Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis. The 14-year-old Belgian talent has garnered attention from top clubs like Arsenal and Barcelona due to his impressive skills. Despite previously turning down Barcelona's La Masia academy, Manchester City's manager, Manuel Pellegrini, aims to secure Patoulidis' services by negotiating a compensation deal with Anderlecht's chairman.

A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort, but has been bailed pending further questioning. Miss Santillan was found strangled and beaten to death in a flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death to come forward. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and is seeking information from those who knew Miss Santillan in London.

A woman named Dawn, who experienced seven miscarriages, was devastated to find out that her friend and housemate, Jamie, stole Â£207 intended for her baby's gravestone. This was revealed on The Jeremy Kyle Show through a lie detector test. Jamie, a convicted burglar, initially denied the accusation but later confessed in a Facebook message. Dawn, feeling betrayed, wanted to honour her baby, Daniel James, with a gravestone, but now feels heartbroken and let down by Jamie's actions.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group, who were previously captured and displaced when ISIS took over their towns in northern Iraq. The freed Yazidis, mostly women, children, and the elderly, were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to the Kurdish regional capital. The release was facilitated by Arab tribal leaders, but the exact motivation is unclear. ISIS has been known for its extreme cruelty towards the Yazidis, a Kurdish religious group, slaughtering and enslaving them. The international community responded with aid drops, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham and England striker, is celebrated in a new animation showcasing his standout season. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', features his goals and celebrations, using a unique animation technique with still photographs. Kane's remarkable season has led to nominations for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards, competing against top players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, supports Brendan Rodgers' continued role as the club's manager despite a disappointing season. Carragher believes that Rodgers should not be judged solely on the lack of trophies and that the team can improve next season with the right signings. He acknowledges the pressure on Rodgers but highlights the importance of stability and the existing squad's potential. The article also mentions Carragher's community work in Merseyside, for which he received a Beacon Award.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic toy gun confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport, who deemed it a security risk. The airport staff also conducted a thorough pat-down of the young boy, which his father, Phil Hayward, described as 'over-zealous' and 'ludicrous'. The toy gun, a Â£6 semi-automatic soft dart gun, was later replaced by the family after their holiday. East Midlands Airport defended their actions, citing government regulations that prohibit any items resembling weapons from passing through security.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed his requirements for an ideal partner, including being a non-drinker, non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, and good at various domestic tasks. Rich described himself as athletic, tattooed, and an outdoors enthusiast. He mentioned his financial stability and willingness to provide benefits to the successful candidate. The ad generated attention, but attempts to contact Rich were unsuccessful.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke aims to implement significant changes to boost the presence of homegrown players in English football. He proposes increasing the minimum number of homegrown players in club squads and redefining the criteria for 'home-grown' status. Five former England managers have shown their support for Dyke's proposals, emphasizing the need to address the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level. They argue that blocking these changes could hinder England's chances of international success and prolong the wait for a World Cup victory. The managers also highlight the lack of opportunities for promising young English players, despite the emergence of talents like Harry Kane, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling.

Demelza Poldark, who was barely showing her pregnancy last week, has given birth to a baby girl, making her husband Ross Poldark a father. The quick progression of the pregnancy from announcement to birth within a short time frame has been noted by fans, who have commented on the show's tendency to depict rapid pregnancies. Despite Ross's heart being taken, his character's popularity as a heartthrob has sparked a desire among female viewers to settle down with him.

Nigel Pearson, Leicester's manager, has called for his team to stay calm and focus on their own performances in their battle for Premier League survival. Despite recent wins, including a last-gasp victory over West Brom, Leicester remains in a precarious position, just three points from safety. Pearson wants his players to ignore the relegation battle around them and concentrate on their remaining fixtures, emphasising that their destiny is in their own hands.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia to Mexico. This journey challenges previous assumptions about whale species and their migration patterns, suggesting a possible overlap between western and eastern gray whales. Varvara's remarkable navigation skills and the discovery of her eastern breeding grounds contribute to a re-evaluation of whale classification and population estimates.

A large section of the seabed, approximately 1,000ft long, suddenly emerged along the coast of Hokkaido Island, Japan, surprising local residents. The new landmass, reaching up to 50ft above sea level, is believed to have been caused by a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow. Geologists and researchers conducted aerial surveys to study the phenomenon, which revealed no prior indications of land movement. The event is not considered related to recent earthquakes in the region.

Gregory van der Wiel, the Dutch defender, has refuted rumours of his impending departure from Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer transfer window. Despite a recent dispute with manager Laurent Blanc, which resulted in his exclusion from the Champions League match against Chelsea, van der Wiel expressed his contentment at PSG and his desire to renew his contract. He emphasised his love for the club, the city, and his teammates, stating that everything is perfect for him in Paris. However, with ongoing speculation linking PSG with Barcelona's Dani Alves, van der Wiel's future at the club may be uncertain.

Carlos Tevez, the former Manchester City striker, is in talks to terminate his contract with Juventus and return to his boyhood club, Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite being on course for a second Serie A title and having a chance at European glory, Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus this summer. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, confirmed that the club is close to finalising the deal but emphasised that Tevez must first end his contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016. Tevez, who started his career at Boca's youth academy, has always stated his intention to finish his career at the club. Juventus, while reluctant to lose the league's top scorer, have acknowledged Tevez's wishes and are already scouting for replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, believes the move would not impact Tevez's national team status, emphasising that his form is the priority, regardless of the club he plays for.

Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, inadvertently tore his trousers during his team's 6-1 victory over Porto in the Champions League quarter-finals. The excitement of the match, which saw Bayern overturn a 3-1 deficit, led to a small hole in Guardiola's left trouser leg, revealing his underwear. Bayern's impressive performance secured their semi-final spot, striking fear into their European rivals.

A multi-vehicle crash in Brisbane's west resulted in ten people, including four children, being injured. The incident involved three vehicles colliding on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale. Several individuals were airlifted to hospitals in Brisbane and Ipswich, with injuries ranging from chest and shoulder pain to abdominal pain and hand lacerations. The highway was temporarily closed, and emergency services, including fire and rescue crews, attended the scene to assist the injured.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil has acquired a new Apple Watch, which he proudly displayed on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from the show Knight Rider. With six games left, Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points in the Premier League. The return of Jack Wilshere from injury is a boost for Arsenal, but former player Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's fitness is a concern, despite his undeniable talent.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby between United and City, despite having sent off three players from both teams this season. The appointment comes after a controversial decision to dismiss City captain Vincent Kompany during the international break, resulting in a suspension for the upcoming Wales match. Clattenburg has a reputation for being one of the Premier League's top referees, despite past accusations of favouritism. The derby holds significant importance as United's recent form has seen them move a point above City, adding extra incentive for both teams.

Bob Katter, an MP of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of assuming Billy Gordon, an Indigenous MP, would resign after being accused of domestic violence and having a criminal past. Katter's statement, which included the phrase "little black puppet on a string," sparked controversy on social media, with critics questioning his choice of words. Katter defended his statement, explaining that he used the term based on his personal experiences and to highlight racial attitudes. He also mentioned federal MPs who became government puppets, assuring that Gordon would maintain his independence.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using her passion for dancing to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Through her videos, she aims to showcase that despite her disability, she can achieve and enjoy life just like anyone else. Dayna wants to change societal perceptions and encourage people to look beyond disabilities, hoping to turn negativity into positivity and motivate others to embrace their differences.

Orlando City, an MLS club with a large Latin-American fan base, has shown interest in signing Javier Hernandez from Manchester United. Hernandez, a Mexico international, has struggled on loan at Real Madrid but remains an attractive prospect for several Premier League and European clubs. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a new contract offer to young talent Andreas Pereira, who is also sought after by various European teams.

A group of three or more individuals committed arson by setting a car on fire at a South Los Angeles gas station early Saturday morning. The driver of the white Dodge Charger had an argument with the suspects, who attempted to carjack him at gunpoint. Although the driver and passengers escaped unharmed, the car sustained significant damage. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident, utilizing surveillance footage to track down the suspects.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from southern Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to engaging in inappropriate and unethical practices. He was accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite these serious allegations, Manuel received positive patient satisfaction evaluations on HealthGrades.com. As part of an agreement, Manuel has pledged not to apply for license reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove that the circumstances surrounding the revocation no longer exist. This case has raised concerns about the chiropractor's conduct and the impact on his patients.

A Russian fighter jet's interception of a U.S. reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea has prompted the United States to lodge a complaint with Moscow. The U.S. claims the Russian pilot acted unsafely and unprofessionally, while Russia alleges the U.S. plane had its transponder switched off, a claim denied by the U.S. This incident follows a similar encounter between a Russian jet and a U.S. RC-135U a year ago, highlighting the frequent interactions between Russian and U.S. aircraft in various regions.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a hotel parking lot in Salt Lake City, days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle was secured in a case with padlocks and chains, but the thief managed to break into the car and forcibly remove the weapon. The agent's gear, clothing, and tools were also taken. Despite evidence found at the scene, the rifle remains missing, and the hotel lacks surveillance cameras. The Secret Service was informed of the theft but could not disclose any security changes.

Luigi Costa, 71, is on trial for the brutal murder of his neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in 2012. Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Forensic evidence suggests that Costa's mental state was compromised by dementia and alcohol abuse, leading to a confused and fluctuating mood during the incident. The defence argues that Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack should be considered, as it could result in a not guilty verdict if proven.

Everton's Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines' excellent penalty record. Barkley's penalty was saved, but Martinez argued that Barkley had the right to take it, and praised his courage. The miss didn't affect the outcome as Everton won 1-0, thanks to a goal from Kevin Mirallas.

Two passengers were found dead in a suspected murder-suicide on a Holland America cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The incident occurred on March 29 during a Southern Caribbean cruise that departed from Tampa, Florida. The bodies were discovered by cleaning staff, and the FBI is investigating the case.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Dutch footballer and assistant coach, has successfully led the Caribbean island team Curacao to advance in the 2018 World Cup qualifiers. Curacao, under Kluivert's guidance, progressed to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF after drawing 2-2 with Montserrat in the second leg, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team will now face Cuba in the next stage of the tournament. Kluivert has a personal connection to Curacao through his mother's heritage and has previous World Cup experience as a player and assistant coach.

Esteban Cambiasso, a veteran footballer with a distinguished career and numerous trophies, believes that helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League would be a significant achievement, akin to winning a cup or a league title. Despite Leicester's current position at the bottom of the table, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances of survival, emphasizing that there are still games left to play and that the team has the ability to win. He signed for Leicester in the summer, leaving Italy after a decade, and has quickly become a vital player, expressing contentment with his life in the East Midlands and the possibility of extending his stay beyond the current season.

A young mother named Gemma is at risk of being denied access to her two children by her own mother, Debbie, due to her irresponsible behaviour. Gemma, who has a history of drinking, partying, and stealing, had previously given custody of her children to Debbie when they were infants. Debbie, concerned for the children's well-being, is considering banning Gemma from her home and the children's lives, as she believes Gemma is unfit to be a parent. The situation has caused tension and emotional distress within the family.

During a football match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored a goal, but the Sky Sports pundits believed there was a foul in the build-up. Chelsea's John Terry made a strong challenge on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, causing him to lose the ball. The pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, agreed that Terry's tackle was a foul and play should have been stopped. Souness described it as an elbow to the back of Falcao's head, while Henry and Redknapp also acknowledged the foul, with Redknapp suggesting Falcao could have stayed on his feet but still deserved a foul call.

A tour bus carrying Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all passengers, including Scott, her husband, tour manager, and driver, were safely evacuated. The fire was captured on video by a bystander, Michael Barnett, who witnessed smoke and flames coming from the rear of the bus. The incident occurred after a rear tire blowout, and the fire destroyed most of the bus's interior except for Scott's Bible. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

A Scottish scientist, Dr. Adrian Quarterman, is developing a space laser technology to harness solar energy and transmit it to Earth, potentially revolutionizing home heating. The lasers will convert sunlight into energy using mirrors and semiconductors, and then beam it down to Earth. This innovation could make solar power more accessible, even in less sunny regions like Scotland. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and the next step is to test the technology in Portugal. While these lasers are not intended as weapons, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the potential risks of controlling such powerful technology.

A convicted paedophile, Stephen Munden, has escaped from a psychiatric unit and is currently on the run. Munden, who has a history of sexual offences against young girls, was last seen leaving a hospital in Hampshire. He is described as having a heavy build, dark hair, and possibly being clean-shaven. The police have launched a manhunt, emphasizing the urgency of finding Munden due to his learning difficulties and the nature of his convictions.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts to Donald Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, who sued Stiviano for targeting wealthy older men. This decision sets a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from the recipients of such gifts. Stiviano's relationship with Sterling, the former LA Clippers owner, was exposed through an audio recording where he made racist remarks, leading to his NBA ban and ownership termination.

Murdoch, as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, now oversees the world's second-largest media conglomerate, which split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on June 28, 2013. The Murdoch Family Trust owns both resulting companies.
Wildfang is a US clothing brand offering a range of apparel with a tomboyish aesthetic for women.
Bessie Smith, an American blues singer, lived from 1894 to 1937.

Speech recognition is a multidisciplinary field that focuses on creating systems to convert spoken language into written text. It combines expertise from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to develop these advanced language processing technologies.

Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley, was a multifaceted English artist and practitioner of the occult, known for his work as a ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer.
Poldark is a British-American drama series that premiered on BBC One in March 2015.
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge is a 1995 Indian film starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, shot across India, London, and Switzerland over a year-long production period.
Timothy Simon Roth, born May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director. Another Tim Roth, born December 6, 1975, is a musician and the last original member of the Canadian metal band, Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married tennis player John McEnroe in 1986 and they had three children together.

Sean Penn is a renowned actor who has won two Academy Awards for Best Actor. He first gained critical recognition for his performances in crime dramas in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Penn's breakthrough came with the drama 'Dead Man Walking', earning him his first Oscar nomination and a Best Actor Award at Berlin. He received further Oscar nominations for 'Sweet and Lowdown' and 'I Am Sam' before winning consecutive Academy Awards for 'Mystic River' and 'Milk'. Penn also directed and starred in 'Into the Wild', which received critical acclaim and two Oscar nominations.

The Earth's history began with volcanic outgassing forming the early atmosphere and oceans, which were initially toxic due to the lack of oxygen. As the Earth cooled, a solid crust formed, allowing for the existence of liquid water on the surface. Plate tectonics has shaped the planet's landmasses and oceans, while changes in the biosphere, largely driven by human activity, significantly impact the atmosphere and other Earth systems. Water is a dominant feature, covering 71% of the Earth's surface.
Nuuk, also known as GodthÃ¥b, is the capital and most populous city of Greenland, located within the municipality of Sermersooq.

The sequel to How to Train Your Dragon features a returning voice cast and new additions, including Cate Blanchett and Djimon Hounsou as Valka and Drago. The film is written and directed by Dean DeBlois, showcasing the talents of both veteran and new voice actors.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed and written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake. The movie pays homage to the sex comedies of the 1950s and 1960s, especially those featuring Doris Day and Rock Hudson. It stars RenÃ©e Zellweger and Ewan McGregor. The film was later adapted into a TV series in Taiwan, airing on China Television and Gala Television in 2010.
The album 'Paris' by Paris Hilton showcases a blend of musical genres, including reggae, soul, and pop rock, in its production style.

Stripes is a 1981 comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman, featuring a star-studded cast of Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, and more. The film marked the first significant roles for several actors, including John Larroquette and Judge Reinhold, and early appearances for Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, and others.
Janelle MonÃ¡e Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own label, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer renowned for her song "Love or Lust," which was featured in the film Deep Cover. She also contributed choruses to iconic West Coast rap tracks like "Gin and Juice" by Snoop Dogg and "Let Me Ride" by Dr. Dre.

The University of Mississippi has a diverse student body, with a majority of its students originating from Mississippi. Approximately 55% of undergraduates and 60% of the total student population are from the state, while 23% are minorities. The university also attracts international students from 90 different countries.
The Mighty Ducks is a film produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet-Kerner Productions, and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy is an actress known for her roles in several television series. She starred as Jenny Matrix in the web series "Video Game High School" and later as Anna Martin in the dark comedy-drama "Unreal." Currently, she plays Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller "Quantico."

Martin Van Buren, an American politician, served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841. He was a prominent member of the Democratic Party and held various senior positions, including Vice President and Secretary of State under President Andrew Jackson. Van Buren played a key role in Jackson's 1828 election and later became Governor of New York to support Jackson's campaign. After a brief tenure as governor, he joined Jackson's cabinet as Secretary of State and later received an appointment as the American minister to Britain.

Camden, New Jersey, is the location of Rutgers UniversityâCamden, established as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and the Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which began operations in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the USA. It is the tenth most populous state and has the eleventh largest total area, making it the largest state east of the Mississippi River. Michigan's unique geography, consisting of two peninsulas, contributes to its popularity for recreational boating.

Penguin Books pioneered the publishing industry in the 1930s by introducing affordable paperbacks priced at sixpence and sold through accessible retail channels like Woolworths. This innovation brought high-quality fiction and non-fiction to a broader audience, democratising reading and making literature more accessible to the masses.
The 2008 film Australia was produced in multiple locations across Australia, including Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music artist who contributed to the genre's global popularity. Excuse My French is a shared title for American rapper French Montana's debut album and an Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama. The film, based on Salama's experiences, faced censorship challenges due to its religious discrimination theme.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 dance film 'Make Your Move', a Romeo and Juliet-themed production with South Korean and American influences.

"Bad Romance" is a song by Lady Gaga from her 2009 EP, The Fame Monster. It was leaked illegally before its official release at Paris Fashion Week. The song became a global hit, topping charts and selling 12 million copies, making it one of the best-selling singles ever. There is also an independent drama film with the same title, released in 2011.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including popular franchises like Shrek, Madagascar, and Kung Fu Panda, as well as standalone hits. They also produced the animated series Trollhunters for Netflix, in collaboration with Guillermo del Toro's production company.

Chris Eubank is a retired British professional boxer who competed for over a decade. His son, Chris Eubank Jr., is also a British professional boxer and has followed in his father's footsteps. Eubank Jr. has held multiple titles in the middleweight and super-middleweight divisions and is currently ranked among the top boxers in the world by various organizations.
Sophia Bush is an American actress and filmmaker, recognised for her performances in several movies, including John Tucker Must Die, The Hitcher, and The Narrows.

Rupert Murdoch, the media mogul, is the chairman and CEO of Fox News, and previously held the same positions at News Corporation, which was the world's second-largest media conglomerate. After News Corporation's split in 2013, Murdoch maintained control of its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox. His son, James Murdoch, is also a prominent businessman, serving as CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
Gal Gadot was one of the highest-earning actress/models in Israel in 2013, primarily from her acting roles.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, commonly known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band popular during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs, a medical condition, can be identified through a radiographic or X-ray examination.
The South Wales Coalfield is a coal-rich area in south Wales, particularly within the South Wales Valleys.
The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football tournament for the best clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It began in 1962 as the CONCACAF Champions' Cup.

Mary of Teck became Queen Mother in 1936 after her husband George's death. Her eldest son Edward ascended the throne but abdicated the same year to marry Wallis Simpson. She then supported her second son Albert, who became King George VI, until his death in 1952. Mary passed away the following year during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
The film Poseidon was a moderate financial success, generating worldwide box office revenue of over $181 million against a production budget of $160 million.

The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was introduced in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton have each won this award three times, making them the most awarded in this category.

Human trafficking is a lucrative criminal enterprise, primarily involving forced labour, sexual slavery, and exploitation. As of 2014, the International Labour Organization estimated that forced labour generates $150 billion annually, with millions of victims exploited for labour, sex, or state-imposed work.
The 2011 film Rio had a sequel, Rio 2, which was released in 2014.

Francis I was a title held by two significant historical figures. The first, Francis I of the Holy Roman Empire and Tuscany (1708-1765), ruled alongside his wife, who held the real power. The second, Francis I of France (1494-1547), was the first king from the AngoulÃªme branch of the House of Valois. Known for his personal involvement in wars against Charles V, he formed a controversial alliance with the Ottoman Sultan, Suleiman the Magnificent. The Italian War of 1536-1538 was a conflict between these two rivals, Francis I of France and Charles V of Spain and the Holy Roman Empire.

Peking University, a prestigious Chinese research university and C9 League member, holds the distinction of being China's first modern national university. Established in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Imperial Academy. Initially, it also served as China's highest education administration body. Consistently ranked as the top university in mainland China, it is colloquially known as BÄidÃ  (åå¤§).
Lemmy was a musician renowned for his iconic look, featuring friendly mutton chops, his unique gravelly voice, and his signature bass playing technique.
Global warming poses a significant threat to human populations, impacting food security through reduced crop yields and forcing the abandonment of inhabited areas due to rising sea levels.

Australia is a 2008 epic historical romantic drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann, featuring an Australian-American-British production. The film stars Hugh Jackman and Nicole Kidman, showcasing a blend of adventure, history, and romance.
Michael Vick is a former NFL quarterback who played for 13 seasons, most notably with the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a rich variety of cultural elements, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather-related beliefs, superstitions, and traditional practices like food and craft-making. It is a diverse oral tradition passed down through generations, preserving Canada's cultural heritage.
The First Motion Picture Unit created over 400 films, blending education with entertainment. Their work included training films and combat cameraman instruction.

James Jones is a renowned name associated with two prominent figures:

- James Jones, the author, achieved acclaim with his debut novel, "From Here to Eternity," which won the National Book Award in 1952 and was adapted into a successful film and TV series.

- James Jones, the basketball player, excelled in his senior year, averaging 25 points per game and receiving prestigious awards. He has won three NBA championships and consistently performed well, reaching the NBA Finals seven times consecutively with LeBron James. Jones is also known for his three-point shooting prowess.
Humphrey Bogart is considered the greatest male star of Classic American cinema, as ranked by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Computer animation is a technique used to create animated visuals, as seen in the Netflix series Trollhunters. This fantasy show was developed by Guillermo del Toro in collaboration with DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon resigned from WWE in 2009, with his resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, the longest-serving actor in the role. He has also narrated various media, including the comedy series Little Britain, commercials, video games, and audiobooks.
Angelsberg is a small town located within the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site is a location that encompasses a diverse range of nuclear-related facilities. It is primarily known for its cleanup project, but it also includes the Columbia Generating Station, a commercial nuclear power plant, and several scientific research centers. These research centers include the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory, contributing to scientific advancements in various fields.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior role, appointed by the President, to act as the spokesperson for the executive branch, including the President, senior executives, and their policies. This position does not require Senate confirmation but is highly visible due to regular media briefings.

Kentucky, nicknamed the "Bluegrass State," is renowned for its fertile soil and the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky, home to Louisville and Lexington. The state is famous for horse racing, bourbon, coal, the historic My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film featuring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston, who is known for her roles in various movies, including The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Sebert, born in 1987, is an American artist known for her singing, songwriting, and rapping. She previously stylized her name as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, two new versions of the song "Despacito" were released: an electronic version by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was a professional wrestling event held annually from 1983 to 2000, initially broadcast on closed-circuit TV and later on pay-per-view. It was organised by the NWA and WCW. The 1985 event was a significant transition, being the first NWA event to be broadcast on pay-per-view. The WWE Network later added the 1983-1986 Starrcade events to its pay-per-view section, rating them TV-MA for their violent content, particularly the 1985 "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A. The 1997 Starrcade was the 15th edition of the PPV event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt coordinator, action choreographer and film director working in the Bollywood film industry.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series created for the streaming service, marking the return of the franchise after a 12-year hiatus since the conclusion of Star Trek: Enterprise.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for several teams, including the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins. He also played in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is a term that refers to two different works: the debut album of American rapper French Montana, and an Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on his experiences in a public middle school. Additionally, British artist Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a prominent figure in the music and film industries as a hip-hop artist, actor, director, and producer.

A floppy disk is a portable data storage device made from a thin, flexible magnetic disk enclosed in a protective plastic case lined with fabric to prevent dust accumulation. It is a common data storage medium, often referred to as a "floppy," "diskette," or simply "disk."

Guatemala's history from the mid-19th century to the late 20th century was marked by instability and conflict. The country endured a prolonged civil war from 1960 to 1996, where the US-supported government clashed with leftist rebels, resulting in genocidal acts against the Maya population committed by the military.
Forceps are handheld tools with a hinged design, allowing users to grasp and hold objects firmly. In non-medical contexts, they are commonly known as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer, a highly rated drama series, premiered its seventh and final season on July 11, 2011, following the success of its sixth season.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the main character of the popular American TV series Lost, which aired on ABC from 2004 to 2010. The show spanned six seasons and 121 episodes, attracting an average of 16 million viewers during its first season.

Matthew McConaughey is an American actor known for his dramatic roles in films such as *The Lincoln Lawyer*, *Bernie*, *Killer Joe*, *The Paperboy*, *Mud*, *Magic Mike*, *The Wolf of Wall Street*, *Dallas Buyers Club*, *Interstellar*, *The Sea of Trees*, and *Free State of Jones*. The 2012 film *Mud* stars McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer, journalist, music producer, and musician. He wrote books such as 'Deep Blues', contributed music journalism to publications like the New York Times and Rolling Stone, produced blues recordings and the 'Deep Blues' film soundtrack, and played clarinet in the 1960s band, the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum, an American artist and engineer, is renowned for his role in completing the iconic Mount Rushmore National Memorial. Following the death of the project's original leader, Gutzon Borglum, in 1941, Lincoln Borglum assumed leadership, ensuring the continuation and completion of this monumental sculpture.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau, featuring an ensemble cast of well-known actors and voice artists. The screenplay is written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams, bringing together talents like Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton in live-action roles, alongside the voice talents of Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

A group of teenagers, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, and others, are the first to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse, having lived in a space habitat called "The Ark." The series explores their experiences on Earth, as well as the stories of Clarke's mother, Dr. Abby Griffin, Ark council member Marcus Kane, and Chancellor Thelonious Jaha, who is also Wells Jaha's father.

The Concert for Bangladesh was a groundbreaking humanitarian initiative that faced initial financial challenges but ultimately achieved great success. It raised significant funds, increased awareness, and set a precedent for future benefit concerts, including Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam, a renowned Indian filmmaker, is recognised for his significant impact on the Tamil film industry and for transforming Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine, a significant concept in American political history, was introduced by Stephen A. Douglas during his debate with Abraham Lincoln in Freeport, Illinois, on August 27, 1858. This debate was part of the renowned Lincoln-Douglas Debates, which comprised seven exchanges between Lincoln, the Republican Senate candidate, and Douglas, the Democratic incumbent. The debates, particularly those in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, attracted massive crowds from nearby states due to the pressing national concern over slavery.

Easy A is a 2010 teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. It features a star-studded cast including Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, and many other well-known actors.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien, is an American author known for her gothic, Christian, and erotic literature. Her writing career started with the publication of 'Interview with the Vampire' in 1976, and she gained critical and popular success in the 1980s. Rice was married to Stan Rice, a poet and painter, for 41 years until his passing in 2002.

Camden, a city in Camden County, New Jersey, had a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. The city's population at the turn of the 20th century was predominantly European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 erotic thriller-drama film, "The Canyons," which was directed by Paul Schrader. The film received critical backlash.

A series of seven debates took place between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the US Senate, and Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate and incumbent Senator. These were known as the Lincoln-Douglas Debates or The Great Debates of 1858.
The ancient Greeks attributed the authorship of the foundational epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey, to Homer. Joe R. Lansdale, an American author, penned the mystery-thriller novel, The Thicket.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a former US Navy SEAL and sniper, was killed on February 2, 2013, by Eddie Ray Routh at a Texas shooting range.

Audioslave was a rock band formed in 2001, featuring renowned musicians from other successful bands. The band included Chris Cornell from Soundgarden, and three members from Rage Against the Machine: Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Wilk, known for his drumming, was a founding member of Rage Against the Machine in 1991 and later joined Prophets of Rage in 2016. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consisted of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle MonÃ¡e Robinson, an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model, released her debut studio album, The ArchAndroid, in 2010. The album received critical acclaim and was released under Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel authored by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town in northeastern Louisiana, serving as the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. The University of Mississippi, located nearby, has a diverse student body, with 55% of undergraduates and 60% overall from Mississippi, 23% minorities, and international students from 90 countries.
The series 'Flaked' was renewed for a second season of six episodes, set to air on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in various political roles in New York, including two terms in the State Assembly, as Attorney General, and as a U.S. Senator. He culminated his political career as Vice President of the United States.

The Soyuz rocket was developed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program. It was commissioned to launch the Soyuz spacecraft, initially with unmanned test flights and then with 19 manned launches. The Soyuz spacecraft, named for the Russian word for "Union," was designed for the Soviet space programme and succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft, originally intended for the Soviet manned lunar missions. This spacecraft is still in service today.
Steve Ditko, a student of renowned Batman artist Jerry Robinson, pursued his artistic education at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine, an American rap metal band, experienced internal tensions leading to the departure of de la Rocha and their subsequent breakup. De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums. In 2007, Rage Against the Machine reunited, performing at Coachella, and their fourth album, 'Renegades', was released in 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a stock market index comprising 30 financially robust companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. One of these companies is Tata Motors, which is traded on multiple exchanges, including the Bombay Stock Exchange, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is a Southeast Asian country located on the Indochina Peninsula. With a population of approximately 92.7 million, it is one of the most populous countries in the world and Asia. Vietnam shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The country has experienced significant economic growth since 2000 and had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among major economies in 2011. Vietnam is one of the few remaining one-party socialist states that adhere to communist principles.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film, marking the directorial debut of John Gatins, who also wrote the screenplay.

Bhagat Singh, a charismatic Indian socialist, gained fame through his revolutionary acts against the British in India. His execution at a young age transformed him into a revered folk hero, inspiring the Indian independence movement.

Aparshakti Khurana debuted in Bollywood with the 2016 Indian biographical sports drama film 'Dangal', starring Aamir Khan. The film, directed by Nitesh Tiwari, revolves around a wrestling competition.

James VI and I, also known as James Stuart, was the monarch of Scotland, England, and Ireland from 1567 to 1625. Despite ruling over two separate kingdoms with distinct political systems, he advocated for a unified parliament, aiming to merge the Scottish and English parliaments. His reign in England was marked by challenges and conflicts with the Parliament.

Danielle Cormack, a New Zealand actress, is renowned for her diverse roles across stage and screen. She began as a core cast member in the soap opera 'Shortland Street', but gained recognition for her parts in 'Xena: Warrior Princess', 'The Cult', and 'Legend of the Seeker'. Cormack's film credits include 'Separation City', and she's appeared in TV series like 'Rake' and 'Underbelly: Razor'. Her most notable recent work was playing Bea Smith in the prison drama 'Wentworth' from 2012 to 2016.
Rob Sheridan, an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, is renowned for his significant contributions to the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor and comedian known for his roles in various comedy films. He starred in "Tommy Boy," "Black Sheep," and the "Joe Dirt" franchise, including the 2015 sequel "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser," which he also co-wrote with Fred Wolf. Spade has been a part of successful comedy ensembles in movies like "Grown Ups" and its sequel.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop, Lady Gaga's album, received mixed critical reviews but achieved commercial success. It debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200, selling 258,000 copies in its first week and becoming her second consecutive US number-one album.
